reviewText:
Transistor is at the same time very similiar to and very different from Bastion. Once again the game starts in a city where some kind of catastrophic event took place and the hero must fight it and maybe find a way to undo it. You'll recognize the art style and the familiar voice of Logan Cunningham guiding you through the game, this time not as the narrator but as a companion.

Even with all the similarities, Transistor ia a very different experience. The setting is much more futuristic. Everything in the game is related to programming language and sometimes you wonder if the city of Cloudbank is a real city or just some kind of complex metaphor. The battle system has a unique mix of action and strategy. Every skill (called function in the game universe) can be placed in an active or passive slot. Besides that, every skill can upgrade another skill, or even itself, leading to a huge amount of possibilities to choose from.

The only negative aspect of the game is that it'll take about half the time to finish it if compared to Bastion. There is a Recursion Mode that works like a NG+ where you can start the game again retaining the level and skills from the previous run but that's it. Besides that minor flaw, Transistor is still a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Short version: This art-house action-RPG comes with an unconventional/semi-turn based battle system, gorgeous music and visuals, a somewhat thin but wonderfully told narrative, and remarkable integration of gameplay and storytelling.  It's a gem of a game with a decent amount of content and is absolutely worth cherishing.

--------

Long version: Transistor begins gently and without a lot of explanation, giving the player just enough information to know what's going on and where to go.  In short, you're on the run from your would-be assassins, fighting enemies along the way.  You have a sword that talks (voiced by Logan Cunningham, the narrator from Supergiant Games' own Bastion), and the game doesn't bog you down with needless explanations of how a lot of the setting's pieces work.  You quickly acquire abilities as you go, and these skills make Transistor special in several ways:

1) Battles in Transistor work somewhat like Diablo's where you can button-mash if you want, but you can also queue up and instantly execute a limited number of attack commands or move a certain distance without enemy reprisal.  The catch is that until your Turn() meter refills over a few seconds, you can't use most of your attacks, so you have to be careful to play conservatively.  At the same time, you'll eventually become strong enough to where you can and should try to stay in real time more often, which works out well since your time-stop ability can leave YOU vulnerable if you're not careful.

You can only equip a few of your skills as hotkey actives at once, and dying restores your health but disables one of your remaining skills until either you have none left, or you win the battle and make a certain amount of forward progress in the game.  This arguably leaves you even worse off than if you'd simply been forced to restart the fight, which you can also choose to do from the pause menu.  (Note that a few areas place you in big battles right after long interactive cutscenes without giving you a save point first; since battles can sometimes be immediately repeated, try not to hit Retry" on impulse if circumstances turn against you.)  Enemies usually don't have a lot of defensive immunities

It's a great game. no doubt. It has a futuristic setting which brings forth many innovative and cool design concepts. Pity the story is abit too short. Overlooking that, the storyline is great. It has a touching ending, one that hits harder than bioshock infinite's ending. It brings forth questions that we must ask ourselves - Do we have to rely on technology? And to what extend? What is the worth of life, and the consequences that follow in the name of fame? How far do we go for our loved ones?
Other than the story, the gameplay is absolutely fantastic. It allows you to customize your spells in all sorts of manner, promoting creativity and encourages people to keep grinding against the same enemies with different approaches. It also buffs the enemies as you progress further into the game, making it much more of a challenge then just a simple hack-and-slash game.
What I like most about the game is definitely the artstyle and music. It fits in perfectly, reflecting on both the initial utopiantheme and the slow descent into the dystopia which the city becomes as one approaches the end. The option to hold tab and listen to Red sing is also a gem. Her voice protrudes out from the ambient yet invigorating background music, giving even more depth to the storyline of the game, singling it out from the conventional hack-and-slash genre type of games.
Overall, it is a beautifully crafted and ingeniusly designed game. Would rate almost 10/10.

Awesome successor to Bastion!
The familiar Bastion template is present, an ARPG with continual narrative and a fixed isometric view.
The gameplay mechanic is more interesting and engaging, with the abillity to plan moves and combine abilities. The progression was well paced, though it seems to expect the player to continue with game+. The art style and music themes were highly polished and fit together excellently.
In terms of criticism, the game could have been a bit longer. Also, the enemies start lacking variety in the later half of the game, and some more varied scenery could have helped.

Supergiant Did it again, an amazingly beautiful game, great soundtrack, and fun gameplay.

Transistor takes a more tactical approach to it's battle system than the more chaotic hack and slack ARPG combat of bastion. In many cases you absolutely need to utilize the Plan() system and can't just rage through with a few good weapons like in bastion. The game also has a slightly more mature artstyle, and I enjoy the elements of art noveau and cyberpunk aesthetics strewn about all of the cityscapes. It really is a gorgeous game. The story is refreshing and takes some unexpected turns, and despite it being a bit too cryptic at times, i enjoyed it and thought it pulled together the game well.

My only complaint is the brevity of the game. Supergiant just leaves you begging for more, maybe we'll get lucky and some form of expansion will be added. That said I still do not at all regret spending $15 dollars on this beauty of a game, however short.

reviewText:
It's difficult but try to forget that Supergiant games made Bastion; whether you liked Bastion or not is not indicative of how you will feel about Transistor.

Obvious points out of the way: sublime art and music. The aesthetics are scintillating, the backgrounds and world are meticulously detailed. The characters and enemies are well animated and designed, mirroring the world around them. There's a very strong noir vibe seeping through what often feels like cyberpunk New York as imagined by Europe. There's every chance I'm just projecting my desire for Remember Me to have been a good game, but I digress.

The gameplay is solid, provided you realise that operating outside of Turn() is very rarely the best option. Transistor gives you a lot of different skills and variety of ways to combine them allowing you to play however you want, additionally the game encourages you to mix up your skills so that you can unlock character information and the Performance Tests" force you to improvise with randomly selected skills. Unfortunately towards the end of the game encounters become quite repetitive and even with enemies evolving it is rare that whatever combo you've perfected by that point won't be just as effective as before. New Game+ is genuinely challenging but by then you are even furthered hampered in choices and will be extremely reliant on a few exceptional skills to get you through the encounters

reviewText:
Transistor, a cyberpunk themed action RPG made by Supergiant Games is set in a futuristic city called “Cloudbank”. You take the role of “Red”, a young women who gains control of an extraordinary weapon. After a mysterious group nearly kills you, you start your journey, slowly puzzling the story.

The art style, music, and narration create a gorgeous, astonishing and captivating place you want to be part of. Beautifully drawn and rich locations where every step is a pleasure to the eyes, the amazing music by Darren Korb, the fantastic voice acting by Logan Cunningham and the memorable, intriguing characters which grow to your heart are not the only aspects that the game has to offer. The combat is remarkably fun and fresh. While you only have one weapon, there are dozens of functions" which you collect on your journey through Cloudbank. Those functions act as perks which can be  combined with each other and/or used either aggressively or passively matching your playstyle.

All  in all Transistor is a masterpiece and is probably my favourite indie game. Not only I recommend on buying the game but the gorgeous soundtrack it offers which is absolutely worth it."

reviewText:
The world looks amazing, the music throughout the game absolutely wonderful, and the gameplay solid, deep, varied and interesting. The amount of skills and the possible different combinations that you get are mind boggling, and most have very significant effects on the way you play the game. Combat can be done strategicaly with the Turn mode, or just plain old regular real time action, and are just equally as viable and fun!

Though you are presented with a central plot, much of the lore is tied to the gameplay in an interesting manner and presented in a way that not only allows you the freedom of choosing how much of it you want to read/see/hear, but also adds to the sublime world Supergiant has created. The game has atmosphere, it has character, and it's a testament to how good Supergiant is at building a world, which in my opinion, is second to none.

Despite how different this game is from Supergiant's previous game, Bastion, to compare both games is inevitable. Cloudbank is in most ways busier than the areas surrounding Caelondia, but its aethetics are darker and more muted. The music in Transistor is a bit more synthetic compared to the more instrumental nature of Bastion's music, but is no less wonderful. Gameplay wise, Transistor outperforms Bastion in every which way, offering more options and a more fleshed out combat system. Narrative wise though, it feels like Transistor falls short of Bastion by way of being just slightly less coherant and emotional. But, it is still really well done and stands on its own really well.

My only complaints about the game is how short it is, because I find myself just wanting MORE. While Recursion mode (New Game+) satisfies my desire for more gameplay, I also want more of the story, more of the music, and more of the world. Also, the game sometimes fails to explains the mechanics of its skills properly, leaving you to either figure some things out for yourself or consult a guide.

Should you play this? Absolutely. Definitely do consider buying the soundtrack alongside the game, but do not hesitate to give the music a listen first by way of free streaming courtesy of Supergiant themselves. I only wish the soundtrack had the different variations of all/most of the songs, such as the BGMs with Red humming to them, or the instrumental versions of a few others.
http://store.supergiantgames.com/products/transistor-original-soundtrack-digital

UPDATE: Supergiant has released an extended version of the soundtrack with the aforementioned humming and instrumental verions.

reviewText:
WARNING: SLIGHT SPOILERS, SO IF YOU HAVE WEAK METABOLISMS, READ THE LAST PARAGRAPH!!!

Supergiant Games have done it again. Transistor is a beautiful game that blends both gameplay and story so fluently that I forget that I am playing a game at times. The story begins with a mute singer who has just experienced her attempted murder, only to be saved by a bystander. The savior's voice and soul are transferred to the sword, which she carries around to find out what is happening to her city, and off you go.

One thing that stood out to me was the narrator's voice this time around makes more sense to actually hear, instead of Bastion's narrator, who you just sort of, could hear all the time for no real explanation. I know this really wasn't much of an issue in Bastion, but I like to see how the writers have grown up even more than Bastion's amazing story, which leads to another improvement: terminals. We've all been there trying to collect audio logs, but this time around, it's a bit different. Since Red has no voice, these terminals provide ways to communicate with the Transistor, which gives the player more motivation to go after them, rather than just skim over the story. Personally, I think this is a genius way to integrate both the present and the past stories of the game into one.

With such a great story, there has to be some glitches involved. My main problem is after the ending. And don't get me wrong, I LOVED the ending. I never thought how that would be the end, and it was a good conclusion to the arcing story between Red and her sword. But the problem is afterwards, the Recursion. In Bastion, there was a reason to play it over, as there were references to how you ended the game before, and as such have a different experience as before. But now, the game was ended with only one choice, so there really was no point to replay it, except for gameplay value. I guess the developers were going for a more linear story, which is perfectly fine, but I just expected a similar weave to the story as Bastion.

Now, I mentioned gameplay before, and it is good. Not amazing, but good. It takes Bastion's hack-and-slash type and mixes a bit of turnbased action. When a Turn is activated, one can move freely across the field setting up attacks, using up your meter above to do so. Once you are done, you then watch your actions and hopefully dominate the field. The catch with using this system is that you must wait for the meter to fill up again before you may attack again, in Turn or out of. I find that is a good balance, but if you aren't able to dominate a powerful enemy in your Turn, then you are pretty much screwed. Luckily for me, I actually liked the Turn system, but if you don't, you may not have fun with the game, especially towards the end with Man enemies, and the final boss. Which brings up what happens when you die. When Red is defeated in a battle (hence the Turn meter is down and you lose all health), she loses a function that you have under the abilities bar, and you can't get it back until you reach two different function stations. This is an interesting aspect, but it can be quite annoying, as it is often random on what you lose. For example, I once lost my main attack function, and was left with my dodge and my load functions, which do nothing in battle without a good attack. I guess this is the point as it punishes you for losing rather than just spawning you to the last checkpoint, but in my eyes, it is ultimately just wasting my time as it adds not much towards my experience except annoyance.

Another issue is the extensive upgrade system. There were many combinations that one could make with their functions, but the problem was the GUI. You had to go through each function one at a time to see what upgrade you could add to a function. This could've been simply fixed by the ability to compare the upgrades with each function, rather than the other lengthy way. Not much of an issue, but it can be hectic near the ending when you have ten functions you have to go through at a time.

Lastly, the art style. Remember Bastion's art style? How alive the world felt? Well, magnify that by 10, and add some city elements towards the environment, and you got Transistor. The colors vibrate off the screen, and you wish that the city, maybe even the enemies, were existent. Really, there isn't much to say, but to just look at. I once just stopped playing and watched the background for a good minute. The artists know to not mess with a good formula, and luckily they didn't.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NO MORE SPOILERS AFTER, LAST PARAGRAPH/VERDICT

Transistor truly adds more to the Bastion formula, but it still latches a bit too closely towards Bastion. However, this isn't a bad thing, as Supergiant Games are playing it safe and not making a completely different game, which is what we want. We want the same feel of atmosphere from Bastion, which we got with more interactions but less replayability. We want the same gameplay feel, which we got with more options but less hack-and-slash. And we want the same story and experience, which we got with more passion but less nonlinearity. So, do I recommend Transistor? If you liked Bastion and like a bit of change, you'll love this new addition. I sure did.

reviewText:
Supergiant Games have a reputation from their previous game Bastion, to create strong stories that host powerful soundtracks and detailed art. Transistor is no dissapointment, this game is huge step up from Bastion, showcasing unique gameplay mechanics, with a fully customizable weapon at hand.

Though this is one of the biggest feautres of the game, the story, soundtrack, design and love for the characters in the game got me through to the end. This game has such a deep story of lost love and the struggles to reunite with that one. Not only is the soundtrack well written and fitting with the game, it flows with the story development and events that occur through your playthrough, the stylised art is painstakingly detailed, and geometrically themed to maintain the futuristic feel in cloud bank.

Though there were few flaws, some people may find the combat mechanic a bit repetitive, though that is merely encouragement to mix the Transistor's abilities around for a different approach during conflict.

The story is well written and heartfelt, while keeping soppiness out of the picture, beginning in the middle of initial conflict, which renders the protagonist unable to speak her mind and leaves the player to discover hidden details along the way, giving a satisfying and over all great ending. If I were to give this game a rating it would have to be 9/10 just because no game is perfect, but this cut so close, I love having a game the doesn't prolong important story development and yet still tells it powerfully, as well as the art and soundtrack winning me over, a truly moving game.
9/10

If I were to give this game a rating it would have to be 9/10 just because no game is perfect, but this cut so close, I love having a game the doesn't prolong important story development and yet still tells it powerfully, as well as the art and soundtrack winning me over, a truly moving game.
9/10

reviewText:
...This game is a work of art. From the gorgeous style, to the genre choice, to the fantastic music, to the characters who initially just seem like ghosts of what they could be, yet slowly grow on you. The lines are well done, and everyone winds up having a personality of some kind that you begin to relate to them.

The combat is fresh, not something I've seen before (and I've been gaming a long time mind you), and they didn't slack there either. I played with a lot of limiters, but even without them, I can tell you that this one will take you a little while to get used to and will definitely test you. It's a strange blend of action, strategy, RPG, turn based combat, and even shooter all mixed together into a masterful blend that I initially dreaded, and by the end of the game (fantastic ending) was in love with.

This is the sort of game that was made with passion and dreams. This is the quality of game and the determination to make a fantasy that stands out amongst other dreams real for us gamers. I highly recommend this game, and I'm not entirely sure what audience I could think of that wouldn't find something appealing here. Talking swords, sci-fi, angry hardware trying to take over the world, over-eager scientists, lasers, giant explosions, godzilla-esque monsters, and VERY frustrating hairstyles... yeah, this game has a lot of nice quirks worked in all throughout. You'll love it.

reviewText:
Transistor has seriously become one of my favourite games of all time. Supergiant were criticised as a one-hit wonders with Bastion but they have come back with the artistic tour-de force that is Transistor. Through the wonderful handpainted art of Jen Zee and the beautiful tones of Darren Korb's soundtrack, you really get sucked into the abtract city that is Cloudbank and it's atmosphere.

Transistor captures that fleeting moment of Red and The Transistor trying to make it through alive and to get to the bottom of everything. The pacing is on form, some people say its quite short (at 7 hours) but I feel its enough to tell the story that it needed to tell without overstaying its welcome. The world and characters gell so well and all feel completely new, helped by the wonderful narration and chemistry between the characters.

Transistor isnt just all pretty picture, the ability system is quite different and completely customisable and promotes experimentation for completely different playstyles and the punishment for dying in game is one of the most original I've seen and actually adds to the experimentaion of the abilities.

In short, to me Transistor feels like a masterpiece of a painting with a wonderful story, good solid gameplay mechanics and a soundtrack ties it up into one fantastic and intelligently beautiful experience.

Transistor is a game that will stick with me for years to come, and for that Supergiant, thank you.

reviewText:
Similar to Bastion, but then again, completely different and unique...

As Transistor starts, it throws you right in without explaining anything at all except for some basic controls as you get into your first combat encounters, so there is a possibility that you might be slightly confused before you get the hang of it. Though once you do, it gets really enjoyable.

While I haven't found the story to be executed in a way that'd make it exactly shine or keep my mind going on about it for days, I'd still say it was a great piece of art to play through. Where Transistor does shine, though, is the combat system mixing real-time action and turn-based planning into one. I couldn't get enough of the unique feeling of satisfaction coming from the massive piles of damage you get once you do things just right.

Being a game by Supergiant Games, Transistor fulfilled my expectations and both looks and sounds just beautiful. While in my personal top list of video game music Bastion still beats it, it's only by a very slight margin that probably wouldn't be visible to the human eye if that list of mine were to be shown graphically. Meaning that if you do like your soundtracks great, this one's for you.

If you do grow fond of the game and wouldn't want to say goodbye after the approximately five hours it takes to finish your first playthrough, there's a New Game Plus mode ready, as well as some challenges obviously designed to make you rage, and, like in Bastion, optional difficulty enhancers that make you gain more XP but obviously ramp the difficulty up.

Transistor is a must-play for any fans of Bastion, and a great game for everyone else.

reviewText:
9.5/10
Look, whatever you're thinking, do me a favor. Don't let go.

Overview
Transistor is an isometric strategy adventure game starring Red, a voiceless entertainer and her anonymous lover, the latter trapped inside a sword-shaped tool known as the Transistor. Join Red and her mentor-turned-weapon through an epic adventure that explores the concept of singularity and discover the secrets of the city of Cloudbank and the mysterious Camerata family.

Story
Transistor manages to take some interesting ideas and delivers them in an interesting way. Though there are a few cutscenes, most of the story is disclosed through the brief (but frequent), private whispers of the Transistor. Red happily listens, creating an authentic, naturally-developing emotional foundation between Red and her weapon.

The story arc is a little predictable and some events could have been presented in more straightforward manners. Transistor has interesting characters and lore but a fair amount of it requires some critical thinking, assumption and the reading of hidden message terminals that share additional information about the city of Cloudbank and a mysterious event known as The Process".

The story is overall pleasant
date:
in large part due to the dramatic monologues of the man inside the Transistor. The game can be completed within 6 hours.

Gameplay
A mix of fast-paced action and turned-based strategy best describes the game's mechanics. You'll explore a large (though linear) world and frequently encounter mobs of enemies. Using dozens of unlockable Functions
recommended: you can tailor your own combat builds in very specific ways for unique effects and take them to battle. Transistor's combat can be played in live action at full-speed or can be played in a turn-based manner by stopping time and planning attack sequences in advance. The latter is advantageous
hoursPlayed: as it allows you to use multiple moves in much quicker succession than is possible in full-speed action.\n\nYou'll be spending quite some time learning the different Functions and the different enemies and how they react to each other. When you're not fighting
voteText:
you're exploring a distopian virtual city while listening to the melancholy of the man inside the Transistor.

Oh! One button is specially assigned to a singing mechanic; holding it makes Red hum to the tune of the music at any given time. Fun touch.

Visuals
You know that feeling when you look at concept art for a game and think "Wow
helpfulPercent: this looks amazing!" and then the game itself looks somewhat underwhelming? Well
votesHelpful: I have good news.\n\nTransistor itself looks like a breathing piece of concept art. Truly
votesTotal: the artistic vision for this game is surreal. Wearing a gorgeous sci-fi aesthetic
votesFunny:
every asset of the game looks like a hand-painted oil painting and is pleasantly wed to modern computer-generated particles and lighting vfx.

Breathtaking visuals. 'Nuff said.

Audio
Transistor is one of the very few games I've ever played where the audio has taken the spotlight.

Rightfully so
commentsCount: too
column16: as the first thing you're welcomed with is a despondent whisper from a strange sword voiced by the talented Logan Cunningham and an ambient
column17: upbeat tune that chillingly bears tones of alarm. It's a very harrowing start that wouldn't have been possible without the incredible audio direction.\n\nThe VO work is top of the line. With a small but carefully-selected cast
column18: the characters are all given fantastic dialogue work. Logan Cunningham takes the forefront as the man inside the Transistor and nails his role perfectly.\n\nThe music might be my favourite aspect of the game. A 23-song OST filled with sci-fi prog
column19: jazz and alternative rock in both instrumental and vocals flavors oozes with personality and strongly enforces the game's visual strength.\n\nThe tracks are wonderfully composed
column20:
mastered and played at the right times to exert emotion from the player. I'm still thinking of Ashley Barrett's "We All Become" everytime I think of Transistor. I seriously recommend getting the official soundtrack to this game.

Technical
I have had no technical issues with the game except for one crash after about 6 hours of continuous gameplay. This was not much of a problem thanks to the frequent autosaves. The game otherwise features PC options you'd expect and supports controllers.

The TL;DR
Transistor delivers a full

satisfying package on all fronts from the gorgeous art style to the enchanting soundtrack to the intricate gameplay mechanics driven by a conspiracy story involving a strange family and an even stranger city.

I encourage the use of a controller. Lay back and relax. You're gonna have a good time.

reviewText: This is easily one of the most beautiful games I have played.  This was recommended by two of my friends and I am so glad I listened.  This is a game to be savored.  If you are looking for cheap thrills and shallow action, then this is not the game for you.  Do not get me wrong, I love that stuff.  But, this game is something altogether different.  If I had to select one word that best described the gameplay and story, it would be elegant.  Beauty aside, this game is really fun and a reminder of what a game can be if the developers really cared about it.  I wholeheartedly recommend this game to any real gamer who loves the art of video games and what this medium can accomplish.  This is one of those games that stays with you.  We need more games like Transistor.  I need them.

reviewText:
I finally reinstalled the game on my account... I played this shortly after it came out, while staying with a friend of mine for a couple of days, and even though it's been a while, I always kept thinking of how truly fascinating the game is.

Please don't get misled by the screenshots, which might make the game look like some cartoony, overly colored game for little children. It isn't. This game truly has an incredible vibe to it, it's like a little work of art.
I will not get into the story, which is something you really should try to discover yourself.Don't spoil it for yourself by reading about it before playing. Just install and play. The game will tell you what you need to know, and will probably captivate you within minutes...that's what happened to me.

The voice-acting, story, the music, the vibe, the art-style... all of that is amazing. It's not hard to learn, but it does get challening after a while. However, the combat is SO much fun, and there is a ton of variety regarding your abilities.

Please try this one. I would recommend to watch some gameplay, but a) that would spoil the story, which would suck a lot and b) it's still a different experience to actually play yourself.
If you are totally unsure, wait for a sale, but I don't think you'll regret this if you like:
- Story
- Atmosphere
- great music
- turn based combat (its pretty optional to use that at least at first, but later becomes essential)
- a game that is not just the 700th remake of another successful game before, or only relies on EITHER story or gameplay. I don't use this phrase a lot when it's about a game, but this IS a little work of art. Beautiful in so many ways, and I am AMAZED I am writing these words, but that, to me, is the best way to describe this.

reviewText:
Transistor, SuperGiant's follow up to the incredible Bastion, somehow manages to improve on their previous offering in every conceivable way.  I'm going to avoid spoilers in this, so I'll be mindfully vague at points.

The music is amazing.  I mean, if you just set it out on its own and listened to it, it is brilliant.  However, more than just that, the music is integral to the plot.  They use the music to tell the story via lyrics.  At times plot and music is blended so well it leads you to question whether they are diegetic or non-diegetic, not unlike brilliant pieces of film such as Trois Couleurs.

The graphics are aesthetically wonderful.  Myself, I've never been a big proponent of attemps to use realism in gaming, I far prefer a well done art style that fits the world we're playing in, and style is something that simply oozes out of Transistor.  From the usage of vibrant colours juxtaposed against stark white landscapes in later games to the deco styling prevalent throughout, you will drool over this game if you have any love of comics, art, or cartooning.  Absolutely wonderful.

The story is a strong narrative told in an unorthodox way.  I'll be honest, this won't be for everyone.  The story isn't spoonfed to you, you need to work for it a bit.  You have to unlock all 3 facets of all your functions, read between the lines of conversations between characters, listen to all the terminal reports and only then, at end game, do you really start to pull everything together into a functional whole.  If you take the time, however, it does make it worth your while.  The game paints a stark portrait of Orwell mixed with Huxley to create a world of immediate and meaningful gratification that overwhelms the populace's drive for freedom and the ability to stand against a tyranny, whether purposeful or merely incidental, from the people who control it.  Hardly new or different in terms of a story, but told very well and in an interesting way.

This game easily creeped into my top 5 of all time, can't recommend it heavily enough.

reviewText:
Transistor is probably the most beautiful game I've ever played.

As you would expect, it's a lot similar to Bastion in some respects, but it's also more complex and engaging.

Visually, the only other game I ever played that maybe looked better is Journey. Maybe. The writing is superb, subtle where it needs to be, but also quite funny, and, best of all, it actually ties really, really well into the gameplay mechanics. I won't get into details to avoid spoilers, but I'll say that Cloudbank is a fascinating setting, and unlike anything I've seen in other cyberpunk tales.

In my opinion, Bastion's main fault was the simplicity of its combat system. It wasn't bad by any means, but it also didn't allow for a lot of depth. Transistor fixed that and created one of the most engaging combat systems in recent memory in the process. It's a mix of real time and turn-based combat that works surprisingly well, where you can mix and match a number of skills, each of them tied to a character in the game, and the more you use them in different ways, the more you learn about the respective character. It's a great way to keep your playstyle constantly changing, and it ties really well into the story.

Darren Korb is back and his music is as good as ever, possibly even better. Ashley Lynn Barrett voices the protagonist, Red, and the songs she sings are not only beautiful, they're all directly tied to the game's story.

And finally, Logan Cunningham is back, which should be reason enough for you to buy this game.

reviewText:
Transistor is an Sci-Fi themed Indie-ARPG, with a kinda similar atmosphere as Bastion, even tho the general story and gameplay differ.

The strongest points in this game are the beatiful and enjoyable music, the wonderful and appealing art, a refreshing combat system, consisting of real-time as well as tactical paused and planned out combat, the flexible difficulty system, where you can change the difficulty of this game in many different ways, and last but not least the way of story-telling through narration, which  reminds me of Bastion.

The story might be confusing at first, but if you listen carefully and read all the descriptions and backstory, you're going to enjoy the amazing and interesting story line of Transistor.

The weakest link of this game is the very short length, even shorter than Bastion, but i'd much more prefer quality over quantity, and this is without a doubt a quality product.

If you enjoyed Bastion, are a fan of Indie-like game or want to experience a kinda different gameplay than usual games, Transistor is the right game for you, but you might want to wait for it to go on sale.

reviewText:
Better than Bastion?  Maybe.  Like the previous offering from Supergiant Games, Transistor delivers on multiple fronts:

1. Visuals: Transistor is aesthetically beautiful in a way that few other games are and if Supergiant continues down this particular road, all of its games will be instantly recognizable.

2. Sound: The same awesome narration with a new voice follows us into Transistor.  It's topped off by another beautiful soundtrack from the Supergiant team that you'll want to listen to many times after completing the game.

3. Gameplay: Where some might have found the gameplay in Bastion a little simplified, Transistor kicks it up with a hybrid turn-based/real-time combat system, numerous weapon combinations and enemies with unique abilities that make battlefield strategizing more of a priority.

4. Story: Perhaps the only place where I could knock this game, Transistor follows in the footsteps of Bastion with a couple interesting twists and a really solid story backed up by bits of in-game lore, but leaves some of the world-building up to player theorizing.  This can be a positive or negative depending on what you're looking for in a game.  Regardless, Transistor still manages to craft a compelling narrative that outstrips a lot of games on the market today.

In short: I can't think of any remotely good reason not to buy or recommend this game.  It's a great example of what happens when a group of developers and artists come together with a solid and unique vision and pull it off.

reviewText: Transistor left me spechless. At the time it came out I didn't even had a chance to put my hands on Supergiant Games Bastion, so I had to play it first, so I could feel the style of its developer. And now that I played both I can say that the game feel was surely saved (if not enhanced). The graphics are just fascinating. Bastion also has great visuals, but the setting here is different and comparing these two is kind of stupid. Can say the same about the music. As a Kid, you had to put up a new home for yourself and the others, you were the only hope, the person that felt kind of sad and scared of the burden, but on the other hand brave and ready for the unexpected. And so is the music. Transistor puts you in a sci-fi city, and the situation Red is in is really tough - her voice is stolen, the man that is close to her heart is stabbed with a somewhat electronic sword, and there is a group of people that are chasing her. Most songs have that post-rock feel to them, which made me melancholic and sad, and relaxed at the same time. But there is one thing I'm sure about - the soundtrack to Transistor is something else.\nSince it's hard to not to compare it to Bastion, I need to say one thing - it really is a great enchanting game, but Bastion is a bit better, imo. There are not much games that give you goosebumps, but both of the games did that to me. !!Bastion Spoilers!! The part where you're carrying Zulf back to the Bastion, accompanied by the Setting Sale, Coming Home song was much more impressive than the Transistor ending. Maybe the culmination part of Transistor should have the ending song being played during it, but anyway, that's just my opinion. Transistor is still a great game, and it's definitely 10/10. I recommend it to everyone who played Bastion, and to everyone who likes the game's plot to make you slightly sad, but satisfied.

reviewText: I really appreciate what they were trying to do with this game, and in a lot of ways, it's very appealing to me as a gamer. Well, in two ways in specific. The first is just how aesthetically pleasing this game is. The world, abilities, enemies, music and artwork is all really well done. The ability system is fun and I find myself wanting a Diablo style game to incorporate a system similar to this because I think it's well done and gives you a lot of customization. reviewText:
If The Great Gatsby were a video game I really don't write a lot of reviews, like, at all. But I enjoyed this game so much; it physically compelled me to do so. Rarely has a video game caused me to spout praises about it to millions of strangers on the interwebs. This one did, big time.

Artistic direction, plot development (no spoilers)
It's hard to talk about this game without mentioning the stylized presentation. Transistor shows influences from Supergiant's previous game, Bastion. Whereas Bastion's toon-like presentation contrasted with the somber themes the game explored, in Transistor, the developers made the game feel almost impressionistic. Cutscenes and plot elements are introduced in parts and pieces on a background palette of neon lights and gilded society. Much like how Bioshock gives you the choice of picking up optional voxaphones, the clarifying parts of Transistor's story are introduced via optional newscasts and recordings. The female protagonist looks like she stepped out from the Roaring Twenties, and the game feels and plays like a jaunt through The Great Gatsby if the book also featured murderous enemies at every turn. The protagonist's accomplice will narrate and banter with her throughout the game. Plot elements are introduced organically, and it's almost too easy to feel the emotions behind choices and actions the protagonist takes despite her being pretty much mute for the entire game. I found myself satisfied in almost every artistic aspect.

reviewText:
Nota completa en Liberen al Geek (Supergiant Games: Bastion & Transistor): http://liberenalgeek.com/2015/09/01/supergiant-games-bastion-transistor/

En el 2013 apareció un pequeño trailer mostrando el nuevo proyecto en desarrollo, Transistor, el cuál nos dejó con muchas ansias hasta su salida un año después. ¿Contexto? Universo Cyberpunk. ¿Protagonista? Red, una famosa cantante a quien le quitaron su voz. ¿Historia? Despertamos al lado de nuestro novio, quien ha sido a♥♥♥♥♥♥ado por una espada, Transistor. ¿Llega al nivel del Bastion? Totalmente pero a pesar de asemejarse en muchos aspectos, también se diferencia en muchos otros.

La ciudad de Cloudbank está siendo atacada por el Proceso, un ejército de inteligencia robótica que está acabando con distintas personas de influencia, como Red. Los responsables de estos ataques son The Camerata, un grupo integrado por cuatro personas interesadas por recuperar la espada y a los cuales perseguiremos en busca de respuestas. El trasfondo de los mismos es muy interesante, cuentan con una personalidad y motivos muy definidos.

La  protagonista no estará sola, ya que el hombre que encontramos a nuestro lado y fue “capturado” por Transistor nos hablará (al estilo de Rucks) y guiará para que descubramos de a poco quién es. O quién era.

El estilo del juego puede parecer similar a simple vista, pero acá se ve un combate mucho más profundo, con la novedad de poder pausar el combate y planear nuestros ataques. En este estado utilizaremos puntos de acción (dependiendo la habilidad nuestros movimientos serán mayores o menores) y tendremos bonificaciones de experiencia si encadenamos combos correctamente.

En esta oportunidad tenemos a nuestra disposición 4 ataques para elegir que iremos encontrando a lo largo del juego y podremos disponer muchas combinaciones entre ellas- ya sea utilizándolas para atacar o para mejorar otro poder-.

En ciertos lugares de la ciudad, podemos acceder a una sala llamada Sandbox, un segmento de playa donde podremos descansar, escuchar canciones del juego mientras disfrutamos una vista increíble (me he quedado horas utilizando este lugar como reproductor de música) y nuevamente aparecen Challenges bastante difíciles, que nos darán experiencia y nuevos tracks para disfrutar.

Visualmente es hermoso, no hay otra palabra para describirlo. Cada rincón, personaje, enemigo y detalle brilla por si solo.

Mención especial al soundtrack que nuevamente es un placer para nuestros oídos, con un estilo muy acorde a la atmósfera del juego. Tenemos la posibilidad de hacer que Red tararee la canción que está sonando en ese momento cosa que hará también automáticamente cuando pausemos el combate.

Luego de finalizar la historia, desbloquearemos el modo New Game +, en el cuál podemos comenzar de nuevo manteniendo nuestros upgrades e items, pero también sucederán cosas nuevas y aparecen ciertos guiños, lo que resulta en una experiencia distinta y no tan forzosa. El juego en sí no es muy largo y seguro se queden con ganas de más (aunque tiene un final más que satisfactorio),  en todo caso si no están seguros pueden esperar a una oferta y conseguirlo a menor precio  (en mi opinión, vale su full price).

reviewText:
I was surprised how different the gameplay is from Bastion. The combat is mostly turn based and there's no environment hazards other than enemies. The system for selecting skills and upgrades is very unique and really encourages trying different combinations. I like how the complexity grows over time, but never feels overwhelming. It has the same clever system as Bastion for customizing the difficulty with debuffs for rewards.

The story is bat-♥♥♥♥ insane, even more so than Bastion. It turns out to be a similar sort of apocalypse, but it feels like most of the collapsing is happening offscreen. I don’t really follow how all the character including your own fits into it. At the same time this makes the world feel very massive.

I miss the destructible and animating environments of Bastion, but these are incredibly beautiful. All the character an enemy design is wonderful. The music is amazingly good, but is much harder to describe than Bastion’s mix of Indian and Western.

It’s tough to live in the shadow of Bastion. This isn’t my favorite game this year and didn’t meet my very high expectations, but I still like almost everything about it and was left wanting more. It probably the most stylish turn-based combat games I’ve ever played. It’s pretty different from almost anything else I’ve ever played including Bastion, so it’s worth experiencing for that.

reviewText:
As a preface, I would like to state that SuperGiant's previous game, 'Bastion,' is one of my favourite games of all time. If I present an obvious bias or compare the two games on unfair grounds, then I appologise in advance.
First let us discuss what Transistor does right. The gameplay presented is the same isometric world navigation that was apparant in Bastion, the major difference being its approach to combat. It abandons the hectic run-and-gun/hammer skirmishes of the former and instead takes a far more intelligent plan and execute method. The player can temporarily pause time and plan out their battle strategy before hitting the pause button again and watching it play out at lightning speeds. The numerous variaties of enemies and the layouts of the battlefields provide ample chances to scratch that 'General Chessmaster' itch. The massive amount of weapons (called 'functions()') alsoadd to the tactical depth of this game. Each weapon can be equiped in one of four wepon slots, where it functions normally, firing lasers, dropping bombs etc. Each weapon may also be assigned to either a passive slot, providing you a powerful, perk-like bonus, or to an upgrade slot, in which one weapon buffs the other (LASERS THAT ALSO DROP BOMBS!?). The amount of combinations is truely staggering and will be greatly apprieciated by gamers who like a more intelligent approach to their combat (myself included).
Next the art style. Although the more charming cartoon-like character proportions from Bastion are gone in favor of a more realistic-(ish) art style, the vibrant colours and tones make a glorious return. The mood and the tone of various scenes are masterfully enchanced by use of reccuring temperatures and unique art assets. The forboding height of Coudbank City, as presented soon after the beggining of the game, is alleviated by the cool yellow and blue lighting, giving it a more distant, lonesome feeling, to give one example.
And the soundtrack, oh my, the soundtrack. I was so thrilled to hear that Darren Korb would be returning and boy does he deliver in the audio department. Echoing guitar riffs and droning synthesizers, alongside beautifully melancholic vocals do wonders to nail the sad, lonely cyberpunk feel that is so greatly apprieciated by big nerds such as myself. Particular standouts for me are 'In Circles,' 'Forecast' and 'The Spine.'
And now to cover what I personally was let down by. The story. WAIT! Allow me to expand. (No spoilers don't fret!) The characters themselves are very nicely portrayed, with excellent moments of individual characterisation, but I took issue with the game's plot, its over-arching story. You are dropped right into the world with zero idea of who these characters are, where you are, or what the hell is going on in general. 'But that happened in Bastion too!' I hear you shout. Yes you woke up in a floating bed in Bastion with zero understanding of what was happening, but this created a sense of wonder as the game's  plot was quickly given to you, (The world blew up, but the Bastion can fix it) and as you progressed the world, characters and other various story flavor was gradually revealed to you in satisfying amounts from level to level. And most importantly by the game's end all questions had been answered. This is not the case with Transistor. Although it does a good job with the aforementioned characterisation and also with the same story flavor being drip fed to you, major components of the the plot are flat out not explained, which frustrated me greatly as it gave me difficulty in understanding vital things such as character motivations. These questions are also not addressed, or at least not in any way a near satisfactory level, by the games end. The final boss in particular was very confusing for me, the fight itself comes out of nowhere and takes place in a very strange location and I found myself thinking 'WHAT THE HELL IS HAPPENING? WHY ARE WE FIGHTING NOW? WHERE-WHA-BUT I DIDN'T.........' and soon after the fight the game ends. The ending itself is rather emotional, but I couldn't get into the mood the game wanted me to due to my extreme frustration and confusuion owing to the fact that the credits were rolling and my questions had not been answered. Now I'm not some fool who only enjoys simple by-the-numbers stories, I understand that not all questions need to be answered, but jesus christ SOME would have been nice. Thematically , the game is not as strong as Bastion. It is clearly attempting to make commentary on topics such as the irrelevance of an individual in a system, and the fickleness of the general public but it falls flat if suitable context is not provided.
To summerise: Wonderfully cereberal combat with powerfull art and sound direction that is only let down by its adequately explained story. Or maybe I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Transistor is probably an afterthought to many gamers out there, but to anyone who has played Bastion, this game is a must buy. To those of you who do not know the majesty of Supergiant games, Bastion and Transistor both share epic qualities that seem to be missing from most games today.

In the simplest way to define Transistor: this is art, truly inspired art. I'm literally at a loss when it comes to reviewing this game. Supergiant manages to pull you into their story and make you feel like you are a part of it. Each character has some unique facet about them that can intrigue the player. Abilities are explained through some fabrication of a character's life. Everything has its mark in Transistor's world. The story is simply magnificent and a main driving point to the game.

As a player, your eyes are met with a glorious palette of colors uniquely blended across the canvas of the game world. Every building, every character, and even every enemy, meshes together in loving unison. Nothing seems out of place and it all looks beautiful. Also, without fail, Supergiant delivers another amazing soundtrack for their game -- to compliment the beautiful scenery and character design, the background music is just as eloquent and wonderous. And to add to the soundtrack even more, the in-game music can be interacted with with the main character. Have you no will to play the game,  the soundtrack alone is worth the price.

As short of a review as this may be, Supergiant did not disappoint -- not even in the slightest. I would highly recommend playing Transistor AND Bastion, if you haven't already. Thanks for your time.

*Disclaimer: This is an opinion, obviously. You do not need to agree :p

reviewText:
Bastion  was my favourite game of 2011. So you could say I was highly anticipating  Supergiant Games  next release -- which was revealed to be  Transistor  in 2013. After a long and patient wait, I've completed Transistor and I would like to share some of my thoughts and perhaps answer how it stacks up to Bastion.

The story revolves around a character called  Red , who seems to be a singer superstar in the city of Cloudbank. After Red wakes up from an assassination attempt by a sinister group of high ranking public figures known as  The Camerata  and realising her voice was also stolen... Red pulls The Transistor out of a mysterious body next to her, and attempts to unravel what exactly happened to her. Little does she know though, that The Transistor can talk, and actually seems to know her. As Red starts to make her way out of the district, she is attacked by an army of robotic intelligences known as  The Process , who seem to be controlled by The Camerata.

The story is more abstract, subtle and darker this time. I would say the story is not as immediatetely likeable as Bastion's story -- as the narrator for Bastion basically narrated and spelled everything out for you in a clearer way. In Transistor, the narrator is also your companion,  (voiced by Logan Cunningham once again, though with a much less gravelly and cool sounding tone) . You are more encouraged to explore the world this time to find out more about Cloudbank's lore instead of relying on the narrator.

What is amazing is how the story also mechanically ties into the gameplay . You come across various slain characters in the story that you absorb into The Transistor, gaining new abilities. Abilities are multifaceted, so each ability can be used as an active/upgrade/passive and can be mixed and matched for some cool possibilities. You unlock character lore by using each ability in one of the 3 types of slots. It's quite a brilliant and elegant way of doing lore if I must say so myself.

You have 4 ability slots which can be upgraded (via leveling up) to have 2 upgrade slots each and you can also unlock 4 passive slots. As you can imagine, this gives Transistor much more depth and customisability this time around compared to Bastion. You can play the game in real time like any normal ARPG... but Transistor also adds a layer of strategic depth with it's new feature called the planning stage -- letting you pause, queue and plan your attacks (with a short global cooldown for all your abilities as a penalty).

There is no overworld hub this time like in Bastion, but you do come across back doors -- taking you to a mini oasis of sorts. Here is where you can access all of the challenges known as  tests . Beating each test unlocks a track for you to listen to. Supergiant also added a feature where if you press tab, Red can hum to every track in the game. I love and appreciate this small attention to detail. You can also gaze up at the stars on your hammock and listen to what the Transistor has to say on your current situation and also play with your process dog named Luna (Dota reference?).

The idol system from Bastion also makes its return, but in the form of limiters in Transistor. Limiters can be toggled on and off making the game harder but also granting more experience with each limiter you enable (up to 10 limiters). Limiters also have their own lore to be unlocked by using them at least once. The game becomes VERY CHALLENGING with 10 limiters enabled and is not for the feint of heart.

The music for Transistor is also incredible once again. It has a bit more of a jazzy and eery sci-fi vibe this time compared to the more upbeat tunes of Bastion. In only 2 games, Darren Korb has cermented himself as one of my favourite game composers of all time. Instant classics, and I can't wait to hear more from this very talented man.

Now, I'm praising this game to the high heavens, but what are some of my  dislikes ? Every time you are taken to 0 health, one of your abilities will be overloaded, and can't be used until you reach the next checkpoint. It is a unique way of handling failure, but I didn't really like the idea of having your skills being stripped from you as it can basically ruin the idea of your build if you make a mistake. It also seems random on what skill you will lose -- which is  severely  punishing -- especially when you are trying to complete some of the later performance tests where if you lose 1 crucial skill, you basically have no hope of finishing the test without restarting the whole test and playing flawlessly. The developers also forgot to add a restart test option to the menu which was frustrating when you are attempting them over and over. Frankly, I also didn't think the tests/challenges were as well designed as they were in Bastion.

Transistor is another monumental achievement by Supergiant Games. It shows they are maturing as a developer. Some people probably thought Bastion's narrator was a bit of a gimmick, and that the story was all it had going for it. Transistor shows that Supergiant also understand how to craft a more mechanically deep and subtle game this time, while still sticking to their strengths of unique story-telling via narration and music.

reviewText:
From the organic ways of Bastion, from the bush and jungle, from levels created by tiles floating up beneath you, we get Transistor. Where the style has evolved into a futuristic, neon-lit, already built level. The world does no longer face the problem of falling apart, but instead it is losing it's style. “The Process”---the equivalent of “The Calamity” in Bastion---covers the creativity made from humans, with a grayscaled and blocky veneer, which seems detrimental to this particular game, where style is easily the highpoint of the experience. The music this time around leaves the closeness of acoustic guitar picking(except for the beach soundtrack) and goes for a more distant, electronic and futuristic atmosphere. Distorted electric guitars and heavy bass lines accorded with ambiance make Transistor a sonically sound experience. The story is very reminiscent of Bastion, but yet completely different. Transistors style and sound design, as with Bastion, perfectly accompanied each other. At points I felt like the levels were specifically made with the soundtrack in mind, because it was so eerily well thought out.

We start of as Red, a singer that lost her voice(it found its way to the soundtrack, though). Standing above a man with a sword in his chest. This sword can talk to us, and also play the roll as narrator. Why only this man can speak through the weapon is unknown to me, since the player ingest other fallen men and women and gain powers through this procedure, but not their voices as with the first body. At this point of the game we don't know who this man is or why we should follow his advice or directions, but it's a game, so we do it anyway. We progress through the levels and gradually begin to understand the situation, “The Process” was a failed experiment from “The Camerata” and the city is conveniently told to evacuate, so we can have that barren emptiness that is so effective when it comes to atmosphere. And The Process is what haunts us throughout the game. As we try to get to the bottom of what happened.

The vagueness and convolution of the story straddles the line of being annoyingly vague and mysterious and intriguing. Where at some points I feel the story would be better told if you knew some of the things you are told in the end. That would make everything feel more natural. In this mysteriousness, the story was overshadowed by the stylistic choices and obligatory gameplay sections. It's unfortunate when Transistor could have been both if they just dropped any pretensions of being deeper and having more substance than there really was. When you get to the end of this two hour game, things will be rather clear, but you will also feel like there should be more, where there are hints and ways the story could have gone that were never shut down or explored in a satisfying way. Despite it not feeling as fulfilling as it seemed to have the potential for, it was enjoyable and the game easily grabbed you and kept you interested up until the end.

The gameplay seems to be a rather contentious subject. I for one, sort of liked it. You could play it like in Bastion, hack and slash, designing your “build” for this purpose. Or you could go a more tactical way, as with a controller I thought would be more suiting. And it was! Although the combat often boiled down to using your tactical slow down time mechanism, killing one foe to then run around, trying not to die until the cooldown ran out, I really enjoyed it. There was tension in that way of playing, trying to just avoid getting hit, spamming RT. While some abilities seemed useless to me, most of them were used at some point due to the fact that you lose an ability when you lose all your health. This was a clever way of making the player use all the different devices, but it's equally as dumb when you have you remake your whole build every time you “die”. The frustration of having to go in to the these access points and try to manage your attacks when half of the things you want to use are unusable somewhat breaks immersion. See Transistor tries to squeeze in a whole bunch of different attacks and combinations into, what was for me, a two hour experience. Perhaps if the game was longer and had more uses for some of the attacks, this wouldn't be so jarring and above all boring. However, when you had the attacks you wanted, with the combinations and everything, the gameplay was a lot of fun. Beautiful colors emitted from every blow, cool sound design and every attack felt more or less powerful, but alas, that didn't mean they were.

All in all it's neat parcel. Well worth it for the creativity. The clumsiness of some decisions didn't come close to ruining the experience whatsoever. So it's a worthy successor to Bastion, and it will probably stay in the same place in my mind as Bastion. As a memory of a stylistically and sonically amazing experience, while the gameplay and storytelling will surely fade out of the collective memory, sooner or later.

reviewText:
Well, I just finished my Recursion and can now finally review the game.

The fights are basically played in an arena - a closed area on the map - and require a lot of thought in skill preparation and use as well as character placement.

Their are two ways to wage a fight. Either you go the classic active way (like any action game), or you can use the Turn() function which allows you to stop time and plan your attacks at leisure.
While in Turn(), everyone freezes and a bar appears at the top of the screen, this bar represent the total of actions you can take (for those who know of it, imagine Legend of Legaia's system). Moving and attacking eats a part of the bar depending of the skill and isn't done right away, instead you plan all hte attack which will be carried out when you finish the Turn(). The actions are then done at lightning speed, often taking a number of enemies to the grave at once with good planning.

About the skills :
You will equip skills (which you acquire by leveling and by finding people) at savepoint, in up to 4 active slots.
Every skill is totally different from another both visually and practically. One can debuff a group of enemies in an area while the other will make you invisible for a while.
Then you can equip those skills as passives for the active skills or for yourself. A skill that makes you drop explosives packets on the ground as active will increase the damage and blast radius of another as passive. Character passives can increase your total HP, reduce damage taken, reduce cost of abilities during Turn()...


The game isn't too short, but not really long. It took me 7 hours to complete my first run and 9 hours to Recurse through the story. Recursion is basically New Game+ wherre you keep everything and replay the story while the enemies are end-game level and randomized through the areas.

The scenario can seem confused, but is very enjoyable with many things to learn.
Apart from the Sandbox - which give acces to a practice area and a number of tests as well as some miscellaneous stuff, a big one being the jukebox - there is no side content.
The art is sublime and serves very well the game. The music nicely compliments the action and events throughout the game and is a jewel to listen to.

I give a solid 9.5/10 for this well crafted game. Really enjoyed it.

reviewText:
*Acknowledgment*

Before I delve into my review of Transistor, let me first state that I am first and foremost a tremendous fan of Supergiant Games. They released Bastion in a time I had ceased playing video games, because I found the quantity over quality insignia that most modern games paraded to be a bit much to bear. With that one release they managed to quickly overturn my decision to abstain from video games. So let me just say (to my own fault) that I have a very soft spot for the company and the diligent employees they keep.

*End Acknowledgment*

- With the acknowledgment in mind, I would like to begin with the good about Transistor.

The strongest point for the whole game, in my opinion of course, is the soundtrack produced by Darren Korb. I could create a lengthy description for this, instead, I will just tell you “listen to the soundtrack”. The man is probably one of the best composers in video game culture, that is all.

The artwork of Jen Zee is a wonderful thing to behold, and deserves to be seen. This game is no exception to that. As well, as always, Logan Cunningham's voice acting is an equal treat.

The setting, world building, and most of the story are solid and deserve recognition.

These things all speak strongly for themselves and no words I can put to them will do them justice.

- Now with the bad.

The battle system, while tremendously innovative, is irritating at best. I respect their attempt, but it clearly needed a great deal more work for creating a sense of balance. It contains all of the elements of strategy and turn-based RPGs that could be considered bad, without any of the rewards, progression, or smoothness. All in all, I feel that this aspect alone could have used at least another few months of consideration, if not a year, as it just feels hastily prepared and self-righteous.

The length of the game adds to the feeling of speedy preparation without consideration. Now don't get me wrong, There are some situations where a small number of episodes, or a few hours of your time can move a piece of multimedia to create a lengthy wake of contentedness. This is not one of those cases and while replay is certainly an option, I feel completely no urge to do so. They try to expand the game with a number of puzzle based battle-challenges to unlock songs within the game, but that would bring us back to the battle system.

The last of what I say rests with the story. This section contains a number of ***spoilers,*** so you should move on if you do not want this portion of the game revealed and I will post when spoilers are finished.

As a majority, the story is interesting, explorative, and at many points, compelling. There are a few points within it, however, that while I understand most probably lend themselves to a particular ideology or thematic pursuit, are what I feel to be gargantuan mistakes in not only the story of the game, but in writing as a whole.

With the exception of Royce, each and every confrontation with the Camerata was unfulfilling, if not completely vapid of context. The characters are introduced in a very dynamic scene where they murder Red's implied and nameless lover, which is roughly the most substance you are going to get from them.

The battle with Sybil is almost confusing because it feels out of place and unexplored. We do have the before mentioned cut scene, yes, but that is all we have at that point and all we get.

Then we move on to Asher, and the seemingly implied arch-nemesis, Grant. Here we receive a number of communications with Asher along the way, which seem to be imploring you to garner at least a little bit of sympathy, if not just understanding for these characters. However, finally reaching them and discovering they had committed suicide, without properly introducing these supposed antagonists was (pardon my language) a ♥♥♥♥-poor story decision and shows (with evidence from the fantastic story writing in Bastion) that this was either a very unconsidered, or very lazy writing decision.

I must apologize for my harshness in this respect, but I feel like I can give nothing but honesty to a company who's work I am so partial of.

I must say that all of the confrontation/interaction with Royce felt incredibly well developed and was by far the most interesting part of the entire tale (with a lot of good progression leading up to it).  However, the suicide of Red not only seemed entirely uncharacteristic of a protagonist who pursued the Camerata so vigorously despite her nameless lover beckoning her not to, and who also fought so desperately to prolong her life against Royce's assail to emerge to a world she can attempt to make a better place, but it also felt like an incredibly unnecessary punch to garner some strong emotional response. At pulling on heartstrings, Red's death was certainly success, but it was at the cost of abandoning all character and story development up to this point.

Now if there is an alternate ending I am unaware of, I would be willing to explore further. With things as they are though, I don't see my self playing this game again at any point in the near future.

***end spoilers***

I had to take a lot of time to mull over how precisely I felt overall with this game, and as much as I truly desire to give this game a thumbs up, I am needing to go with the opposing thumbs down.

I do wish Supergiant a great deal of success and hope that any future releases are true gems that speak for the greatness that I know they are ultimately capable of. Also, perhaps my response to Transistor may be best summed up by the Buddhist phrase “Expectation is the root of all disappointment”.

Many people are really loving this game, and I will continue to have my gamer soft-spot for Supergiant Games, but in continuing with honesty, this game needed more development and consideration for gameplay and story and I'll just have to sit-back an enjoy the soundtrack and artwork while waiting for the next release.

reviewText:
Think of it as Diablo 2 with an optional turn-by-turn mode in a beautiful art deco apocalypse.

To boil it down, you choose between 'functions' (which work like attacks in Pokemon: of many, you only get four at once) to mow down robots in a gorgeously-rendered future city.

The kicker: every few seconds you can pause the action, move about, and queue up a combo of attacks. When you unpause, you whoosh about the battle spitting explosions. You've got a few seconds of helpless fleeing - then you're off again, chaining up attacks.

Trust me: nothing beats laying down three consecutive damage multipliers on a high-level enemy then knocking them off in a single hit.

Difficulty can be raised with optional handicaps called Limiters.

There's a clever system around the functions themselves, too: any function can modify another or provide a passive bonus. I.e., you can add a quick-firing attack to a slower one – increasing the slower attack’s speed, but forgoing the quicker attack entirely.

reviewText:
Transistor is a fantastic game. The artwork is beautiful and the combat is challenging and fun. Dying doesn't make the fight feel unfair or impossible, it simply makes you plan your skills and tactics better for the next time. There are tests much like those found in Bastion to really test your skill which are indeed difficult, yet certainly accomplishable, and they reward you with a song for completing them that you can listen to in the game at your leisure. The boss fights in this one are actually fun too, and satisfying to complete.
The plot is interesting and grips you as you uncover the mystery for where everything went wrong (and there's even a reason for the *silent* protaganist! gasp!). The protagonist(s) feel alive and you genuinely care for them, hoping they can see it through to the end and make everything better. The game took about 6 hours for me to complete the first playthrough while taking my time, so it's certainly not too short but not long either.
The music is also very nice and fits well where it comes up, often pumping you up or feeling very haunting. My only gripe is that perhaps it is a little bit TOO similar to Bastion in the world-building and certain other aspects (though I can't blame them for it, nor do I dislike it, as Bastion's my favorite indie title.) Despite that, I honestly can't say there's anything I really  didn't  like about this game. Not a ton of replay value for those that don't fall in love with it, but the same could be said for any game. For 20 bucks it's a wonderful indie title worth experiencing. And drop 10 more for that sweet soundtrack!

tl;dr: This game is challenging, beautiful, and amazing. Buy it.

reviewText:
Transistor is an RPG by the creators of Bastion. Similarly to their previous game, the art, story, and sound design are all fantastic. The combat is a weird hybrid between real-time and turn-based that will probably be hit-or-miss with most people. The robust skill system was incredible and is probably one of Transistor's best features.

The combat is different than most other games. You can move and attack in real time, but you'll find it difficult to survive without using the Turn() feature. Turn() pauses the game and allows you to plan out your next few movements and attacks. The planned actions will then be executed very quickly, without the enemies being able to attack or move. Turn() then goes on cooldown for a few seconds and most of your skill won't be usable. This creates a turn-like tempo in the the fights where you attack with Turn() and then play defensively when it's on cooldown.  The combat takes a little getting used to and won't be for everyone, but it really works well with the skill system.

The skill system is one of the games best features. I didn't unlock all of the skill on the first playthough, but there are at least 16 of them. Each skill can be used in 3 ways.
1. Active Skill: The skills you use in combat. You get 4 active skill slots.
2. Augementation: Each active slot has two augmentation slots which alter the effect of the active skill.
3. Passive Skill: Each skill has a different passive effect when placed in one of the 4 passive slots.

Although this seems to be overly complex, you only start with a couple skills, the 4 active slots, and an augmentation slot for each of them. You gain additional skills and slots when you level up so the game does a good job of easing you into the skill system. Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of pushing you to experiement and try new skill combinations. I had a lot of fun experimenting with the skills and trying to find effective combinations.

In conclusion, Transistor is a great game. If you liked Bastion, or are a fan of turn based RPGs, you should get this game. If you're unsure that you'll like the combat, you should look at a couple gameplay videos, but try not to spoil the story for yourself.

reviewText: I usually trudge through a game's actual gameplay to get it over with, but Transistor's gameplay was so enjoyable and solid that I found myself playing through the entire game again the very next day. The deep customization of your abilities with the various Functions(), the blend of real time frantic play with the powerful frozen planning of Turn(), and difficulty scaling done right make all the game extremely enjoyable to play. There are unbelievably powerful ability combos in the game, but you're always facing enemies that can meet the challenge. If you're not, then there's still the combat modifiers and restrictions you can add.\n\nStory-wise, the world is significantly more sparse and spare than Supergiant's previous title, Bastion, but it seems to be an intentional choice: a bit of mystery allows for varied interpretations and a long narrative shelf life, which is what I think they were going for in this game. I think they leaned a little too far in the direction of limiting information, but the game doesn't suffer for it too much. I think the endgame buildup and final fight were excellently executed and they are going to be a favorite among the games I've played.

The story is somewhat the games weakpoint as it is somewhat vague but very open to interpretation so it will give you some food for thought. >>> I WILL NOT TO SPOIL ANYTHING, things will be clear after the fact, I really like this developer and I want to support >>> them in their indeavors, since they are doing something new and interesting.
