reviewText:
Transistor and the Studio's previous title Bastion, have some similarities. I may refer to Bastion for some notes, however to avoid confusing those who haven't played Bastion, I will refrain from mentioning it if possible.

For the short version of this review:
+ Absolutely fantastic art style, which can be seen in the environments, as well as enemy designs and your own character.
+ Beautiful soundtrack, still listening to it now. Most of the songs (if not all of them) have been uploaded to Supergiant's official youtube page to listen to.
+ Narration has plenty of dialogue for optional parts of the game, as well as lines during combat.
+ Planning takes the center stage in combat. Transistor mode allows you to stop time, to set out some orders and execute them.
+ 10+ abilities you can select from, all with interesting combinations to try out.
+ NG+ brings stronger enemies and some new lines of dialogue to your second playthrough
- The game is pretty short, I only got about 8 hours from the first playthrough.
- Not the most challenging game, but it can become difficult if you add in 'limiters' in the form of extra difficulty options.
- Frequent freezing if you've been playing for a few hours at a time, including during combat. I've heard of crashes, but haven't experienced them myself yet.
+/- PC controls are pretty good, but may require you to get adjusted.
+/- Story leaves a lot to personal interpretation, while some solid conclusion is given, some may not be content with what is there.

Now for the details.

Story
This is a bit touchy, as I feel most of the story is really revealed in the second half of the game, or at the end, so I won't go into to much detail. At the start of the game, you're introduced as, Red a famous singer who has lost her voice and her friend to a strange group of individuals. Your friend's mind is thrown into a sword, the Transistor, which is the only weapon you'll use through the entire Journey. You begin following the only trail you have, seeking answers. Why you? What is their end goal? What is happening to the city? As your progress, you'll get your answers, and you'll watch as the world around you changes. Will you be truly satisfied with these answers though?

Enivornments and Art Style
This is mostly subjective I suppose. However the art style present feels unique, or at least like a mix of other influencing styles. The blend of realistic environments with this strange cyber-esque world creates a very surreal feeling to the world, which is only further added to by the art style. Enemies encountered called 'processes' are very machine like in nature.

Soundtrack
The soundtrack is an interesting mix of genres, with Darren Korb's personal spin on all of them. Individual songs vary quite a bit. Some songs are very dramatic vocal heavy pieces, that will have you just gushing over the singer's fantastic voice. Other's will get you deeply rooted into the atmosphere, providing a great backdrop for walking around the interesting enviroments. There is of course, good combat music as well. I'm still listening to the sound track, as I write this review actually.

Narration
This is where the mention of Bastion has to come in. Bastion (as most of you likely know) had a great narration system, which had an interesting personality narrate your actions throughout the game, highlighting key moments. Transistor uses the same voice actor, for a slightly different system. Instead the narrator, is an actual character, or rather your sword. That's right your sword talks to you throughout the game. He will comment on specific spots and regions, his thoughts and opinions. Sarcastic remarks are thrown around as well occasionally. In combat he will make comments based on your actions, such as when you execute a turn, or if you lose too much health.

While this is personal taste, I find this style of 'narration' much more interesting than Bastion's narration. In Bastion, it seemed as if he was just telling the story of the protagonist, maybe even to someone else. In Transistor, he plays a character, he frequently talks to Red, not some ambiguous audience. This adds some personality to both Red and the Transistor. As he spoke throughout the game I grew an attachment to him, and a level of appreciation. Red and the Transistor also seem to grow together throughout the game, even if they are only small subtle ques. I suppose this is a bit hard to convey though, as Red can't speak.

Gameplay
The gameplay is relatively simple at first, you have four abilities at your disposal, that can be activated with the right click and aimed with the mouse. You move with ASWD or left mouse click. It gets a little more interesting when the Transistor mode is brought in. Transistor mode allows you to stop time to move and use your abilites to plan your attack, and then execute it. Then of course, there's a cooldown between turns. This is probably the meat of the combat, more options besides your four abilites will open up to be used in interesting ways.

Your four abilities have one initial modifier slot. These modifier slots obviously modify the ability, using other abilites. For example, Crash can be modified with Jaunt to be usable inbetween turns. Or you can combine Ping with Crash to proc mini-stuns on your target. Eventually you can unlock two modifier slots for your abilities which will introduce more options. Such as a Crash that splits into three projectiles and explodes on impact. Keep in mind there are about 10 abilities, so the combinations can get a bit crazy. This however, makes it all the more fun.

Overall:
It's a fantastic game with plenty to offer in terms of execution and style, but it feels lacking in the amount of content it has to deliver. It may be a normal length singleplayer game (by today's standards), it still doesn't offer a large quantity. However the quality debatably makes up for the short length. For some, this will leave a lasting impression, an experience you won't forget. One that has such a unique combat system, combined with a beautiful soundtrack, art style, and presentation. If you don't care for that stuff however, this game might not be your sort of thing. Don't expect an open world sandbox experience.

Final Rating: 7.5 / 10

This won't be very in-depth, and will only cover the basic aspects of the game. Click here for my full review.[www.thatvideogameblog.com]

Transistor is easily my game of the year, and one of my favourite RPGs of all time. Over time I've looked back at the experience and I've come to the conclusion that, of all the games I've played in the past fifteen years or so, Transistor may just be the best out of all them. I ended up clocking in at around thirteen hours, but that includes the time in which it was alt tabbed to write my review. In created few hours, I played one of the most complete, engaging, immersive and beautiful games ever made. Without a shadow of a doubt, Transistor is a masterpiece.

Mechanically, it plays out like an isometric RPG in the vein of Fallout, but with real-time elements and less skills to upgrade. The end result is a very smooth combat experience that still has a heavy emphasis on strategy without ever being overbearing or overcomplicated. Players use the Turn system to pause the game, queue up a series of attacks, and execute them. Once this is done, they will have to wait a short while before pausing the game, forcing them to play in real time, which more often than not means running for cover and re-positioning yourself as your enemies go on the offensive.

reviewText:
A good game, although didn't get the same feelings I did playing Bastion. Ending was a bit disappointing, and it felt way too linear compared to the first one. For the positives, really nice way of having the combat.
You can choose between either action styled combat similar to what Bastion had, or a more strategy focused approach, which in a way was similar to Frozen Synapse. Also they kept the artstyle similar to Bastion, but improved a lot on it as well.
New to this game is also a really nice flexible ability system, where you can decide to use your new weapons as weapons, additions to old weapons or as passive abilities. This makes it so that you have seemingly endless options when it comes to your playstyle.

In my opinion no characters aside from the main character were noteworthy, which is kind of a shame, since that contributed a lot to Bastion's atmosphere.
I shouldn't really be comparing it this much to Bastion, as they aren't directly related to each other, but I think a lot of people wanting to buy this is because they want it to be a similar experience.
As a conclusion I'd recommend this game to everyone who liked Bastion, but it doesn't quite live up to the expectations (storywise) I had after playing the first one.

reviewText:
I planned on 'acquiring' the soundtrack after finishing Transistor.

Instead, I bought it.

That should pretty much sum up how much I enjoyed this game...

On more specific notes...

Combat: The combat is brilliantly designed, challenging and engaging, with a level of -meaningful- customization that actually hurts to think about. I never 'settled in' to a particular playstyle, because I felt compelled to experiment.

Music: It is not only *expletive* amazing, but your character can and *is* be an integral part of it. This is the only game I know of where music is almost more immersive than the story.

Graphics\Animation\Art\etc: Look at the screenshots above and then imagine it barely does the game justice. The travel sequences alone are just... yeah...

reviewText:
Transistor: Not a bad game. Supergiant play to their strengths, which is an isometric 3d world with beautiul art, a sweet soundtrack and a narrator that narrates everything about you in a nice rich voice.

The problem I have with it is largely that, though. Supergiant stuck to their strengths and did not really push much of any boundaries, and it wasn't really that novel; Bastion 2.0, really.

The main innovation is in the combat system, which I do sorta like - hate having to use Turn(), love how all your attacks work as primary attacks, upgrade modules or passive items. I also like the semi-online aspect, where you can see ghosts of other people, a'la Dark Souls. (At least, I'm pretty sure they are, and I'm sure the numerous polls you use are actually being formed by other players voting as well)

One bug I had, which wasn't fatal, but severely annoying in that my game randomly locks up for maybe 3 seconds when I do things like attack.

Worth buying -- if you've played Bastion, though, might want to wait until it's like $15 or cheaper instead of the full $20, because they feel like the same game almost.

reviewText:
I just beat this game and here is why you should buy it.
Good:
- Very good engaging story
- Superb music
- Beautiful artstyle, especially during the cutscenes.
- Combat system is like nothing you've seen before, with the choice of switching between real-time and a planning mode, without either feeling superior.
- Very deep upgrade system that let's you play like you want to play.
- Has a New Game+ mode called Recursion that randomizes enemy encounters, so you can replay it with added difficulty if you feel like it.
- Has a 'limiter'-system that allows you to change the difficulty on the fly with various different debuffs/buffs to you and the enemies respectively. Adding difficulty this way gives bonus exp.
- Has checkpoints that allow you to change your loadout almost every 2-3 minutes.

Bad/not as good:
- Took me 4 hours to beat, could have been a little longer, but wasn't needed. It provided the necessary closure.
- The gameplay is mostly just moving from fight to fight. You walk a (mostly) pre-determined path and once every 2 or 3 minutes you fight something. Not sure what they could have done to make this better though, since I found the combat system really enjoyable.
- Some of the lore is locked behind your combat abilities, and this lore is unlocked by using the abilities as just a normal ability, as an upgrade to an existing ability, or as a passive bonus. I understand that this is done to make you explore different ability-combinations and to try out all of the different combinations, but I found it annoying that I had to change away from my favorite loadout if I wanted the complete story.

The game mechanics, including fights, are far better and improved comparing to Bastion. They are easy to master, very nice to handle on both 360 Pad and mouse+keyboard. No problem there at all everything is great. The turn-based and real-time combat mix works PERFECT. I was afraid of this before the release but it turned out to be just amazingly done making you want to use both and blend them together.
Skill/Functions/Character development is innovative and give you a lot, and I mean A LOT of different possible builds and the game itself/story development does a great job on encouraging you to switch your tactics as often as you can.

Although. After finishing I think, that I liked Bastion a little bit better. Probably because it was first and it was a surprise. The only thing I'd like Transistor to have is a bit more lore given to you by the narrator. Not through the people's description which you can find, but through the sword itself. Like Bastion did it.

If you haven't played Bastion and you're thinking about getting Transistor: Play Bastion first.
If you played Bastion and you're thinking about getting Transistor: Please, by all means.
If you do not like how the game looks, or you are not into the SciFi or anything: Well, if you read it - try it. Sometimes we appreciate something that we do not necessarily like at first sight.

Took me ~8 hours to complete. I was taking my time though, reading everything I could find.

Game as close to perfection as this happens very rarely. Do not think, buy and play!

9+/10. Along with Bastion and both Portals on the top of my All Time Masterpieces list.

reviewText:
A bittersweet tale accompanied by beautiful artwork and soundtrack, Transistor truly is a gem that should be played by many. It excels on many levels, and has definitely become one of my favorite games up to date.

The story of Red, a singer gone mute, and her companion sword, the Transistor, is told with just the right amount of ambiguity and subtle cues. Decidedly leaving some questions open while you play, Transistor invites you to piece it together yourself - the little hints regarding Red's background and how she ended up on her own are stunning to put together. Paced just right, it is truly a unique experience for the player.

The gameplay, too, is quite fun. The mixture between turn-based strategy and action helps the player to find their own rhythm - a rapid, high-risk approach, or a carefully planned out attack: It is up to the player. Furthermore, the RPG elements of this game are very entertaining. Even though I found myself very comfortable with a certain set of functions early on, the game encouraged me to try out new combinations both through story and challenge incentives. I have to say that I am glad that they did, for I've long left my original set behind. And now with New Game+, one can explore even more of its versatility!

And of course, Transistor stands out as a visually stunning, and audibly well told tale that was to be expected from Supergiant Games. Like Bastion, all assets have the beautiful 2D quality to them, and take it to the next level. Jen Zee's art direction is impeccable and truly comes to shine in this beautiful game. Darren Korb's soundtrack complements the visual side of it with a  jazzy and relaxed style, truly emphasizing the artwork of the game.

Transistor is a game that every gamer should have in their library. Every aspect of it is outstanding - gameplay, visuals, soundtrack and storytelling - and thus makes it a gem worth having.

reviewText:
A good game, although didn't get the same feelings I did playing Bastion. Ending was a bit disappointing, and it felt way too linear compared to the first one. For the positives, really nice way of having the combat.
You can choose between either action styled combat similar to what Bastion had, or a more strategy focused approach, which in a way was similar to Frozen Synapse. Also they kept the artstyle similar to Bastion, but improved a lot on it as well.
New to this game is also a really nice flexible ability system, where you can decide to use your new weapons as weapons, additions to old weapons or as passive abilities. This makes it so that you have seemingly endless options when it comes to your playstyle.

In my opinion no characters aside from the main character were noteworthy, which is kind of a shame, since that contributed a lot to Bastion's atmosphere.
I shouldn't really be comparing it this much to Bastion, as they aren't directly related to each other, but I think a lot of people wanting to buy this is because they want it to be a similar experience.
As a conclusion I'd recommend this game to everyone who liked Bastion, but it doesn't quite live up to the expectations (storywise) I had after playing the first one.

reviewText:
Transistor is a game best described as unique. The game looks, plays, and sounds like nothing else out there, and, even more impressively, exexuctes nearly all of these innovative ideas to perfection. The best game of 2014 so far.

Pros:

- The combat. It's a hybrid of turn based strategy and arena action a la Bastion. The standard mode allows free movement and usage of up to 4 equppied abilities (mostly) without cooldown. Pressing space initiates Turn(), which allows you to expend a set number of action points to move and perform abilities at hundreds of times the speed of the standard mode. Turn()'s cooldown length varies based the percentage of action points you used, and all abilities are locked while these points regenerate. Its a brilliant system made more so by the enemy design that forces you to quickly and strategically switch between the two modes.

- The customization. Every ability is a function that can be equipped as an active ability, a passive ability, or overload an active ability with additional functionality. Additional memory and slots to equip functions unlock as the game progresses, allowing for a staggering number of highly unique loadouts. This system allows for nearly any playstyle imaginable to be viable. Using a method in one of its three roles unlock additional backstory material, strongly encouraging experimentation without ever forcing anything. Losing all health in a battle temporarily locks an ability each time it happens, further encouraging creative loadouts while waiting for the locked ability to restore.

- Tests and limiters. The game features 23 tests (and additional Access tests available only on a second playthrough) of your ability to use Turn(), to survive unwinnable situations, to clear enemies with only select functions available, and your speed in standard combat. The majority of these tests are very well designed and often very challenging. All are entirely optional and unlock tracks for the music player. Similarly, limiters are fully optional abilities unlocked at various points in the story that can be equipped to increase the challenge and XP gain of combat. They're a clever way to provide and reward customizable difficulty.

- The art and music. The screenshots and videos on the store page really don't do it justice. Transistor is one of the best looking and sounding games ever made.

- The story. Like Bastion, the critical parts of the story are delivered largely through narration. Unlike Bastion, the non-critical majority of the story is found in terminals, function descriptors, and view points that are all fully optional and found only through exploration. All of it is interesting, well written, and best left to experience on your own.

- New game+. Transistor calls NG+ Recurse." This allows you to play through the game again with all of your abilities and limiters from before. Enemies also retain their abilities
date:
however. Recurse also provides access to higher player levels and additional tests that are not unlockable in a single playthrough.

Cons

- Some of the dialogue is a bit weak.

Notes:

- The story is much better than it gets credit for. That said
recommended: it's much more abstract that what you usually see in games. There's a good chance you won't like it if you're looking for a story that gives every question a clear resolution. This applies especially to the ending.\n\n- The game is about 5 hours long on first playthrough. Recurse can likely double that. I think it's good enough to justify a $2-$4 an hour price tag. If you don't

reviewText:
Like Bastion? Transistor features a story of similar originality and heart, an even more engaging form of tactical gameplay, plenty of options to mix and match, and another cast of vibrant, loveable characters. The game is eager to give you room to draw your own conclusions, which to some may seem perhaps a little lazy, but the pieces are all there. The theme of the story can be said to be individuality and creation, and as such the story follows suit, allowing you to make of Cloudbank whatever you please. But don't trust the hype, give it a go! It's worth the full price and more.

Story length: ~6 hours, if you don't die a lot.
Extras: Limiters, achievements and 'Tests' extend the game by a few hours, plus Recursions. Exploring every inch of Cloudbank and its voice acting will easily double your game hours.

reviewText:
Let me start of by saying that what I write below is from the eyes of a person who has recently finished Transistor.
At the beginning I knew this game was going to be good. The narrative pulled me along - and the world never lost it's curious nature. I found myself wanting to know what was next every moment I played. Something unique about transistor personally, for me. I haven't seen many games that pulled me a long the way it had.

From an Artists perspective - may I just say this game is gorgeous. It's truly beautiful. I tried to savor every single location because of it. The immense use of color and vibrancy in some areas is literally awe inspiring. The designers and Artists who put their time into this game must have really enjoyed the whole process - because I can't fathom anything of this quality being made without considerable love and devotion to it.

Gameplaywise? This game was challenging and fun. The way combat worked was unique to itself - and I enjoyed how much customization your abilities had. It's honestly impressive and fun to sit there figuring out how to build a character. I found myself drawn to a combination of summoning my pet luna and using her in conjunction with other control abilities. But there were so many different ways to go about this.

The soundtrack, well.. how else can I put it? I'd have bought this if it were just /music/ it is so wonderful. But the narrative it flows along with can't be put to the side, either. The narrative the game follows gives quite a few on the songs an amazing meaning to the lyrics and themes - I enjoyed listening to each song and seeing how it told things the story hadn't quite covered.

The story - my god the story. I'm not the toughest guy in the world, but I sure as hell don't cry over nothing. Without revealing too much, let me tell you the person who made this game's story was a genius. It's so beautiful on so many levels. I pride myself on the ability to take something away from a game's meaning and message - and this is a game that has a beautiful message at it's heart.

If I had to say one thing about the ending, I would say it was exactly what I wanted - but not what I had expected whatsoever. You are always on your toes during the whole experience - you never quite see where it's going - and that's the most amazing thing I've ever experienced in a game of 2014. I reccomend this to all of my friends - and pretty much the whole gaming community.

This is something you don't want to miss. It's truly something that won't be forgotten. 10/10

My only complaint would be that the game is a bit on the short side but that is fixed by new game plus letting you keeping all your upgrades and functions while starting from the beginning of the game again. Transistor is a enjoyable albeit short experience that I can recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
First off Transistor was amazing. Another unique world elegantly crafted by Supergiant Games, very interesting gameplay I loved to tinker with and another OST that suplemented the atmosphere of the world of Transistor.

>>> I WILL NOT TO SPOIL ANYTHING, things will be clear after the fact, I really like this developer and I want to support >>> them in their indeavors, since they are doing something new and interesting.

Main character Red, is strong, resilient, and graceful, even though silent trough out the game (like in Bastion), trough her (players) actions becomes adamant in her mission.

The male chacater (also the narator) is someone who doesnt want be THE hero, but HER hero, he has great Hero Complex issues. He starts off being very misterious and then (almost forcibly) changes, similar to a drunk man confessing his feelings (but considering how and when it happens thi analogy is perfect), but he find liberation in his stupor and completes his as a character (nearly). I didnt like him that much, since I expected him to be something else, but I can see some of myself in him, even though I dont like it.

Enemies are awesome, the main antagonist(s) are interesting, they have motives and drives, they arent EVIL in the traditional sense of the word, but they are aganst Red (protagonist, ergo, you). You want to find out about more about them.

Gameplay and story are fused and work and play well together, its rewards you. Skill and upgrade system is nothing like I have ever seen, and is a breath of fresh air, it limites yoou in a way to make most of what you have and the way you want to play. I hope I see something like that in another game.

Story is tightly knit, it has its path and follows it, there is no clutter or bloat to spread the hours. It gives you a great satisfaction to learn more and explore the world that is before you.

Music is amazing! That is all, I am listening to it right now.

Is this more of the Bastion type game? Yes, BUT this just proves there is more ways to skin a cat,  you can see Bastions influence, but only in very very general sense, as you play and imerse yourself you see that Transistor is just a sister to Beastion, related, yes, but completely separate person.

Just, buy and play it. Be happy.

reviewText:
Just a great game all-around.

Most everybody that's interested in this game will be comparing it to Bastion, so we'll go with that metric.

In terms of gameplay, Transistor is quite different than Bastion.  Yes, they're both top-down hack-and-slashes at heart, but while Bastion's beating heart lies squarely in twitch/dodge/attack mechanics, Transistor is a more contemplative experience with its Turn() system.  In fact, the grand majority of Transistor ends up playing much more like a tactics game than a hack-and-slash game; use of skills outside of Turn() is limited and you'll spend most of your time outside of Turn() playing keep-away.  Some people may find this a downgrade, but if you're the sort of person that enjoyed Bastion and also logged hundered-hour files in tactical RPG games (myself included) you'll find yourself comfortable in the world of Transistor.

In terms of style, Transistor is very much cut from the same cloth as Bastion.  That's to be expected when Bastion was such a beautiful and lovingly crafted game.  Painterly visuals abound, and Darren Korb (music) and Logan Cunningham (primary voice actor) are both back in top form, as I'm sure everyone not living in a cave is aware.  Come for the audio-visual niravana, stay for the gameplay.

As far as criticisms are concerned, stability of the game is still a bit lower than could be desired at this point; I had to play around with the files of the game to overcome the dreaded startup crash bug that many people have been complaining of.  A minor criticisim:  If you're the sort of person that doesn't play around with the dynamic difficulty system (Bastion's Pantheon : Transistor's Limiters) you may find the game easy once you've unlocked some of the more powerful functions (I found it a bit trivial even with half the limiters on).  A New Game + feature and use of all the limiters is an easy remedy for those wanting more gameplay and more challenge.

Three things that are fab:
# Turn() system and executing sets that make you feel like a genius
# Wonderfully detailed world and story
# Extra story exposition linked to use of Functions for that extra bit of OCD fodder

Three things that are butt:
# May not work immediately on some computers
# No Steamplay support as of yet
# A bit easy for those seeking a teeth-grinding experience

All in all, Transistor is a wonderful nugget of a game that you shouldn't hesistate to pick up, even at its introductory price-point.  If you liked Bastion for its artistic elements, you'll love Transistor, and if you enjoy tactical games you may end up liking Transistor even more than Bastion.  I know I did!  The main story lasted me roughly nine hours when doing everything available, and I have a bit of a completionist bent.  I have just started a New Game+ session.

reviewText:
A bittersweet tale accompanied by beautiful artwork and soundtrack, Transistor truly is a gem that should be played by many. It excels on many levels, and has definitely become one of my favorite games up to date.

The story of Red, a singer gone mute, and her companion sword, the Transistor, is told with just the right amount of ambiguity and subtle cues. Decidedly leaving some questions open while you play, Transistor invites you to piece it together yourself - the little hints regarding Red's background and how she ended up on her own are stunning to put together. Paced just right, it is truly a unique experience for the player.

The gameplay, too, is quite fun. The mixture between turn-based strategy and action helps the player to find their own rhythm - a rapid, high-risk approach, or a carefully planned out attack: It is up to the player. Furthermore, the RPG elements of this game are very entertaining. Even though I found myself very comfortable with a certain set of functions early on, the game encouraged me to try out new combinations both through story and challenge incentives. I have to say that I am glad that they did, for I've long left my original set behind. And now with New Game+, one can explore even more of its versatility!

And of course, Transistor stands out as a visually stunning, and audibly well told tale that was to be expected from Supergiant Games. Like Bastion, all assets have the beautiful 2D quality to them, and take it to the next level. Jen Zee's art direction is impeccable and truly comes to shine in this beautiful game. Darren Korb's soundtrack complements the visual side of it with a  jazzy and relaxed style, truly emphasizing the artwork of the game.

Transistor is a game that every gamer should have in their library. Every aspect of it is outstanding - gameplay, visuals, soundtrack and storytelling - and thus makes it a gem worth having.

reviewText:
Transistor: Not a bad game. Supergiant play to their strengths, which is an isometric 3d world with beautiul art, a sweet soundtrack and a narrator that narrates everything about you in a nice rich voice.

The problem I have with it is largely that, though. Supergiant stuck to their strengths and did not really push much of any boundaries, and it wasn't really that novel; Bastion 2.0, really.

The main innovation is in the combat system, which I do sorta like - hate having to use Turn(), love how all your attacks work as primary attacks, upgrade modules or passive items. I also like the semi-online aspect, where you can see ghosts of other people, a'la Dark Souls. (At least, I'm pretty sure they are, and I'm sure the numerous polls you use are actually being formed by other players voting as well)

One bug I had, which wasn't fatal, but severely annoying in that my game randomly locks up for maybe 3 seconds when I do things like attack.

Worth buying -- if you've played Bastion, though, might want to wait until it's like $15 or cheaper instead of the full $20, because they feel like the same game almost.

reviewText:
I just beat this game and here is why you should buy it.
Good:
- Very good engaging story
- Superb music
- Beautiful artstyle, especially during the cutscenes.
- Combat system is like nothing you've seen before, with the choice of switching between real-time and a planning mode, without either feeling superior.
- Very deep upgrade system that let's you play like you want to play.
- Has a New Game+ mode called Recursion that randomizes enemy encounters, so you can replay it with added difficulty if you feel like it.
- Has a 'limiter'-system that allows you to change the difficulty on the fly with various different debuffs/buffs to you and the enemies respectively. Adding difficulty this way gives bonus exp.
- Has checkpoints that allow you to change your loadout almost every 2-3 minutes.

Bad/not as good:
- Took me 4 hours to beat, could have been a little longer, but wasn't needed. It provided the necessary closure.
- The gameplay is mostly just moving from fight to fight. You walk a (mostly) pre-determined path and once every 2 or 3 minutes you fight something. Not sure what they could have done to make this better though, since I found the combat system really enjoyable.
- Some of the lore is locked behind your combat abilities, and this lore is unlocked by using the abilities as just a normal ability, as an upgrade to an existing ability, or as a passive bonus. I understand that this is done to make you explore different ability-combinations and to try out all of the different combinations, but I found it annoying that I had to change away from my favorite loadout if I wanted the complete story.

reviewText:
Transistor is just beautiful. The design, the art style. It's just second to none.
Also, the soundtrack. It's a masterpiece.
The game mechanics, including fights, are far better and improved comparing to Bastion. They are easy to master, very nice to handle on both 360 Pad and mouse+keyboard. No problem there at all everything is great. The turn-based and real-time combat mix works PERFECT. I was afraid of this before the release but it turned out to be just amazingly done making you want to use both and blend them together.
Skill/Functions/Character development is innovative and give you a lot, and I mean A LOT of different possible builds and the game itself/story development does a great job on encouraging you to switch your tactics as often as you can.

Although. After finishing I think, that I liked Bastion a little bit better. Probably because it was first and it was a surprise. The only thing I'd like Transistor to have is a bit more lore given to you by the narrator. Not through the people's description which you can find, but through the sword itself. Like Bastion did it.

If you haven't played Bastion and you're thinking about getting Transistor: Play Bastion first.
If you played Bastion and you're thinking about getting Transistor: Please, by all means.
If you do not like how the game looks, or you are not into the SciFi or anything: Well, if you read it - try it. Sometimes we appreciate something that we do not necessarily like at first sight.

Took me ~8 hours to complete. I was taking my time though, reading everything I could find.

Game as close to perfection as this happens very rarely. Do not think, buy and play!

9+/10. Along with Bastion and both Portals on the top of my All Time Masterpieces list.

Transistor was... good. I say that with a little trepidation as overall the package is well rounded - aesthetically, sound, animation, story, attention to detail. The gameplay however seems somewhat at odds with itself. It's nowhere near as seamless or fluid as Bastion, perhaps intentionally, which to me feels like a step backwards despite the added 'tactical' depth. A lot of the enemies often feel cheap, and while on one hand I can praise the game for making me switch up my combat build consistently, the real reason I switched so much was because none of them really felt right.

Overall I'd say 7.5/10, with the missing points purely because of the wanting combat which is a damn shame. Dat Jen Zee art tho. Dat Darren Korb music tho. Dat Logan Cunningham voice tho. Damn.

reviewText:
The presentation is bold but not overwrought. The music is fantastic and a mix of ambient songs with five vocal tracks that call back to the plot of the game itself. “Red” is a character of unfortunate circumstances who must piece together what happened to the city she inhabits.

Combat is done in pseudo turn-based mode, or all in real time. The mechanics of combat remain very fresh due to the skill system. Each skill can be used in its own right, or slotted into another skill to serve as an enhancement to the base skill. Therein lays the dilemma, do you use this skill as a main skill or a passive skill? There are certainly rewards for changing up your build as well.

There is a sizable amount of optional content. Lore is tucked nicely in with combat skills you unlock as you progress through the game. The tutorial is there but it isn’t patronizing, in fact it’s one of the best I’ve seen in years. Controller support is in the game as well as a native support of keyboard and mouse. The controls are responsive for the most part, some skills can require a bit more precision than Red sometimes wants to give.

Transistor is easily in my top three games for 2013/2014. The whole experience is rumored to be 3-9 hours (depending upon play habits) but the retail price of $19.99 is easily far for a stunning experience.

(edit: played most of the game, but not all of it. It took ~12 hours. I am not the fastest player ever however.)

reviewText:
Transistor is a fantastic game. The artwork is beautiful and the combat is challenging and fun. Dying doesn't make the fight feel unfair or impossible, it simply makes you plan your skills and tactics better for the next time. There are tests much like those found in Bastion to really test your skill which are indeed difficult, yet certainly accomplishable, and they reward you with a song for completing them that you can listen to in the game at your leisure. The boss fights in this one are actually fun too, and satisfying to complete.
The plot is interesting and grips you as you uncover the mystery for where everything went wrong (and there's even a reason for the *silent* protaganist! gasp!). The protagonist(s) feel alive and you genuinely care for them, hoping they can see it through to the end and make everything better. The game took about 6 hours for me to complete the first playthrough while taking my time, so it's certainly not too short but not long either.
The music is also very nice and fits well where it comes up, often pumping you up or feeling very haunting. My only gripe is that perhaps it is a little bit TOO similar to Bastion in the world-building and certain other aspects (though I can't blame them for it, nor do I dislike it, as Bastion's my favorite indie title.) Despite that, I honestly can't say there's anything I really  didn't  like about this game. Not a ton of replay value for those that don't fall in love with it, but the same could be said for any game. For 20 bucks it's a wonderful indie title worth experiencing. And drop 10 more for that sweet soundtrack!

tl;dr: This game is challenging, beautiful, and amazing. Buy it.

reviewText:
Transistor is an RPG by the creators of Bastion. Similarly to their previous game, the art, story, and sound design are all fantastic. The combat is a weird hybrid between real-time and turn-based that will probably be hit-or-miss with most people. The robust skill system was incredible and is probably one of Transistor's best features.

The combat is different than most other games. You can move and attack in real time, but you'll find it difficult to survive without using the Turn() feature. Turn() pauses the game and allows you to plan out your next few movements and attacks. The planned actions will then be executed very quickly, without the enemies being able to attack or move. Turn() then goes on cooldown for a few seconds and most of your skill won't be usable. This creates a turn-like tempo in the the fights where you attack with Turn() and then play defensively when it's on cooldown.  The combat takes a little getting used to and won't be for everyone, but it really works well with the skill system.

The skill system is one of the games best features. I didn't unlock all of the skill on the first playthough, but there are at least 16 of them. Each skill can be used in 3 ways.
1. Active Skill: The skills you use in combat. You get 4 active skill slots.
2. Augementation: Each active slot has two augmentation slots which alter the effect of the active skill.
3. Passive Skill: Each skill has a different passive effect when placed in one of the 4 passive slots.

Although this seems to be overly complex, you only start with a couple skills, the 4 active slots, and an augmentation slot for each of them. You gain additional skills and slots when you level up so the game does a good job of easing you into the skill system. Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of pushing you to experiement and try new skill combinations. I had a lot of fun experimenting with the skills and trying to find effective combinations.

In conclusion, Transistor is a great game. If you liked Bastion, or are a fan of turn based RPGs, you should get this game. If you're unsure that you'll like the combat, you should look at a couple gameplay videos, but try not to spoil the story for yourself.

reviewText: I usually trudge through a game's actual gameplay to get it over with, but Transistor's gameplay was so enjoyable and solid that I found myself playing through the entire game again the very next day. The deep customization of your abilities with the various Functions(), the blend of real time frantic play with the powerful frozen planning of Turn(), and difficulty scaling done right make all the game extremely enjoyable to play. There are unbelievably powerful ability combos in the game, but you're always facing enemies that can meet the challenge. If you're not, then there's still the combat modifiers and restrictions you can add.\n\nStory-wise, the world is significantly more sparse and spare than Supergiant's previous title, Bastion, but it seems to be an intentional choice: a bit of mystery allows for varied interpretations and a long narrative shelf life, which is what I think they were going for in this game. I think they leaned a little too far in the direction of limiting information, but the game doesn't suffer for it too much. I think the endgame buildup and final fight were excellently executed and they are going to be a favorite among the games I've played.

reviewText:
I could go on and try to write a detailed and objective review of the game, and try to look at it from different angles, but I can't. I can think of extremely few titles that are as much of a product of love and care, as detailed and as emotionally engaging as Transistor. It's not a single element that does it - it's everything in the game coming together in one awe-inspiring work of art that is unique and completely breathtaking, From its artwork and environment design to its themes and backstory, its fleshed out and relatable characters and its heartrendingly tragic story and conclusion. I went in with really high expectations, which I usually really try not to do, but not only were my expectations met, they were exceeded in all aspects. There wasn't a single thing that stood out to me as being there just as a filler - everything looked and felt like it had an important role and was relevant to the overarching plot. It says so much with so little, and invites you to explore the world yourself, which you undoubtedly WILL do, because the immersion I felt playing Transistor has only been matched by 2 titles in all my years of playing games since the NES era. The amazing attention to detail is not only worthy of the highest praise and enhances the atmosphere hundred-fold, it also serves to strengthen the emotional connection you feel to Red and Breach(). And the music... Oh my GOD, the music. I really, genuinely can't find words to describe it. The way it's interwoven with the story, the way it reflects the environment and the way it changes with it, the absolutely tear-inducingly gorgeous vocals of Ashley Barrett, the way it peaks and dips at key points, the intensity and beauty of it made me shed tears so many times. The small touches like the Flourish and the humming are incredible additions. The humming especially is one of the saddest things in the game in terms of its significance.
I don't want to touch on the story itself, because that's something one must experience on his own, but I will say this: Transistor isn't a dystopian RPG. It isn't a tactical or strategic action RPG. More than anything, it's a tragedy with a heart-rending love story interwoven into it; a tale of choices and consequences.
I CANNOT recommend this game more. I could go on praising it forever, and it deserves every last bit of it. I don't know how Supergiant did this. I can't fathom all the work that went into Transistor and its soundtrack, but it was worth every bit, because what they started with the gorgeous Bastion, they did so much better with Transistor. They have grown so much in so little time, and I mean that in the best way possible. THey've developed and matured as a studio even more.
Of course, they won't get the recognition they deserve, because people will be too busy praising the next cookie-cutter bland multi-million dollar AAA title, likely a shooter, and Transistor won't win many awards"; it likely won't be GOTY or whatever other overhyped title people care about. But really

reviewText:
Let me start of by saying that what I write below is from the eyes of a person who has recently finished Transistor.
At the beginning I knew this game was going to be good. The narrative pulled me along - and the world never lost it's curious nature. I found myself wanting to know what was next every moment I played. Something unique about transistor personally, for me. I haven't seen many games that pulled me a long the way it had.

From an Artists perspective - may I just say this game is gorgeous. It's truly beautiful. I tried to savor every single location because of it. The immense use of color and vibrancy in some areas is literally awe inspiring. The designers and Artists who put their time into this game must have really enjoyed the whole process - because I can't fathom anything of this quality being made without considerable love and devotion to it.

Gameplaywise? This game was challenging and fun. The way combat worked was unique to itself - and I enjoyed how much customization your abilities had. It's honestly impressive and fun to sit there figuring out how to build a character. I found myself drawn to a combination of summoning my pet luna and using her in conjunction with other control abilities. But there were so many different ways to go about this.

The soundtrack, well.. how else can I put it? I'd have bought this if it were just /music/ it is so wonderful. But the narrative it flows along with can't be put to the side, either. The narrative the game follows gives quite a few on the songs an amazing meaning to the lyrics and themes - I enjoyed listening to each song and seeing how it told things the story hadn't quite covered.

The story - my god the story. I'm not the toughest guy in the world, but I sure as hell don't cry over nothing. Without revealing too much, let me tell you the person who made this game's story was a genius. It's so beautiful on so many levels. I pride myself on the ability to take something away from a game's meaning and message - and this is a game that has a beautiful message at it's heart.

If I had to say one thing about the ending, I would say it was exactly what I wanted - but not what I had expected whatsoever. You are always on your toes during the whole experience - you never quite see where it's going - and that's the most amazing thing I've ever experienced in a game of 2014. I reccomend this to all of my friends - and pretty much the whole gaming community.

This is something you don't want to miss. It's truly something that won't be forgotten. 10/10

reviewText:
Not that I ever doubted that videogames do qualify as art, but Transistor should make it obvious to anyone.

The game's artwork is done in a gorgeous, colourful style of cyber-Art Nouveau with maybe a touch of Noir (oh, that does sound really pretentious, doesn't it... what about the nods to certain paintings I imagine seeing in for example the posters? even worse? ok.)
As probably expected, it has an amazing soundtrack, and you can even (sort of) interact with it in the game (Transistor has a hum button, and you won't know how great that is until you played.)
The story is tragic and delivered spot-on. between terminals and the great narrator you're left to fill in the blanks about the place you're in, but the picture practically paints itself. Ha... The narrator is also the same voice as in Bastion, yet somehow the role he plays manages to be entirely different this time around.
Very importantly, the game isn't lacking in its set of mechanics either. The combat system is deep and highly customisable, with not only the options of building attacks and defenses but real-time and turn-based mode as well. The limiters available can raise the difficulty if so desired. The game is just a little short, but definitely replayable in NG+.

Overall, Transistor is just awesome. Get it.
I'm already wondering what game Supergiant Games will come up with next - I bet it will have a great soundtrack.

reviewText:
Alright, first and foremost let me point out that I have recommended this game, which will contrast with what will sound like a negative review. If it comes off that way it's because I felt like Transistor could have been so much more, but standing next to Bastion it's withering in the shade. Overall it was an enjoyable experience, but at the end of the day I'm glad I got it on sale or I might have been very disappointed.

Let's start with the things I enjoyed about the game. The thing that jumps out first is that there's a lot of love behind this game. You can tell that Supergiant wanted to really connect with their audience by creating an immersive world and characters that you can sympathize with. The real-time/active-time combat tries new things while staying grounded in somewhat familiar territory for most strategy/rpg fans, and being able to 'socket' abilities into other abilities makes for some interesting emergent play-styles.

Now for the things I didn't find very enjoyable, or thought could have been done better:

First- about that immersive environment Supergiant wanted to create in Transistor. Personally, I felt like that was a total whiff. They should have called this game Esoterica, because it's filled with fluff that is never explained. It's like picking up a sci-fi book you've never read before and know nothing about- picking a random page in the middle, and reading for four hours. By the end you know more than you did at the beginning, but you're still lost for the most part.. you're missing fundamental information to make sense of the story.

As far as the characters go, I wanted to feel connected to them- I read every little bio and sought out every OVA station to learn more about the world and its inhabitants- but it feels hollow. Like they're trying too hard to live up to Bastion, which achieved greatness in both gameplay and storytelling almost effortlessly.

I found the narrator" in this game to be completely obnoxious. In Bastion the narrator added a lot of flavor and backstory to the world

reviewText:
If there is one thing I value most in single player games it is atmosphere, and above all else, Transistor has the best atmosphere of any game I have ever played to date. This game is beautiful in every sense of the word. The visuals are stunning with mind-blowing attention to detail. The world is immersive, fascinating, and thought provoking. The audio, oh lord the audio, not only does this game feature my absolute favorite soundtrack of any video game I have ever played, but it fits the ambience in a way that is truly beyond words.
Without giving away anything, the story is intriguing to say the least. It absorbs you from the very beginning and makes you want to keep playing to find out more and more about the world. The characters are equally as interesting and mysterious. The game really makes your imagination run wild.
The gameplay is simple when you want it to be, as well as complex and difficult should you choose. It is almost a turn-based game but not quite. The core mechanics revolve around pausing fights and executing movements and attacks. Very simplistic on paper, but with the amount of customization available with all of the abilities you obtain, it has endless replay potential.
I can honest to goodness give this game a 10/10 rating, the only possible gripe I could have with it is that it wasn’t longer. Without a doubt it is my favorite game.

reviewText: A spiritual successor to Bastion? Well, that's right, but it's not just that. This game has a whole lot of content to be explored, such as the backstory of Cloudbank, the reasons behind the Process starting their attacks on Goldwalk, how and why Red got the Transistor and what's the connection between her and the one inside the Transistor. The battle system couldn't be more impressive, as you must have a lot of vision on what will happen to decide your own actions in a turn, taking into account not only the reactions you cause with your actions, but the actions the enemy may take when you attack. One such example is the Younglady (no spoilers are given), which can be somewhat frustrating at first, but it still makes you want to keep trying untill you finally manage to break the pattern. This not to mention the huge amount of possibilities there are to use the Functions in many different ways, using them as Active, Passive or Upgrades. I was very satisfied with the story, gameplay, visual, soundtrack... The game as a whole is astonishing. I highly recommend giving it a try if you like RPGs, and even if you don't enjoy RPGs that much, you may change your mind with this game.

reviewText:
Transistor in many ways expands on the unique elements of Supergiant's earlier title, Bastion. First and foremost is continued use of Bastion's characteristic piece-by-piece narrative structure, this time with the help of a new narrator whose rough mumbling voice is surprisingly well suited to the staggered delivery. The game further draws inspiration from Bastion's niche musical style, bringing that surreal feminine voice to the fore with a hummed melody over almost every track in the game and continuing with the dark isolating tunes that leave the player stuck within the character's head in an unknown world.

Using a similar camera and layout structure as Bastion, Transistor's gameplay sets itself apart through a series of equippable nodes collected throughout the story, each with its own unique effect depending on whether it's used as the base attack, an upgrade to a base attack, or a passive item. These nodes can be temporarily sidelined when your health runs out in combat and, as challenges become harder and your collection of nodes becomes larger, you'll find yourself shuffling them about into new combinations before each new stretch of the game, crafting hundreds of different attacks from the dozen or so nodes you will collect.

This game is gorgeous, by the way. The colors are mind-numbingly vibrant at times and the in-game stills give you that same giddy feeling you get when flipping through an Art of ..." book for your favorite movie or game. If eyes could weep
date: well... never mind.\n\nWhile many of the things that make this game a masterpiece are drawn very clearly from the success of Bastion
recommended: Transistor stands alone in much the same way as Tolkien's books outside of the LOTR or Monty Python's work outside of The Holy Grail have done. It is a much desired expansion of Supergiant's own storytelling and game design.\n\n**The soundtrack is on Spotify for anyone who's curious."

reviewText: A spiritual successor to Bastion? Well, that's right, but it's not just that. This game has a whole lot of content to be explored, such as the backstory of Cloudbank, the reasons behind the Process starting their attacks on Goldwalk, how and why Red got the Transistor and what's the connection between her and the one inside the Transistor. I was very satisfied with the story, gameplay, visual, soundtrack... The game as a whole is astonishing. I highly recommend giving it a try if you like RPGs, and even if you don't enjoy RPGs that much, you may change your mind with this game.

reviewText:
Not that I ever doubted that videogames do qualify as art, but Transistor should make it obvious to anyone.

The game's artwork is done in a gorgeous, colourful style of cyber-Art Nouveau with maybe a touch of Noir (oh, that does sound really pretentious, doesn't it... what about the nods to certain paintings I imagine seeing in for example the posters? even worse? ok.)
As probably expected, it has an amazing soundtrack, and you can even (sort of) interact with it in the game (Transistor has a hum button, and you won't know how great that is until you played.)
The story is tragic and delivered spot-on. between terminals and the great narrator you're left to fill in the blanks about the place you're in, but the picture practically paints itself. Ha... The narrator is also the same voice as in Bastion, yet somehow the role he plays manages to be entirely different this time around.
Very importantly, the game isn't lacking in its set of mechanics either. The combat system is deep and highly customisable, with not only the options of building attacks and defenses but real-time and turn-based mode as well. The limiters available can raise the difficulty if so desired. The game is just a little short, but definitely replayable in NG+.

Overall, Transistor is just awesome. Get it.
I'm already wondering what game Supergiant Games will come up with next - I bet it will have a great soundtrack.

reviewText:
Transistor was an absolute delight to play through. Definitely not a walk in the park but it also wasn't super easy. The experience is definitely best enjoyed playing with the added difficulty provided by Limiters and in Recursion Mode where you keep your progress but replay through the game with heightened difficulty. Enemies will scale up to your current level and ability in the game in the 2nd go-around.

Praises aside, the game has some performance issues that will hopefully be ironed out in future updates and I feel like the experience was missing something. I was under the impression that the game would have some more puzzle features given an earlier sequence, but it's almost entirely combat oriented with Turn() being a strategic, puzzle mode.

I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a a refreshing experience and who enjoys an immersive environment. This game's captivating soundtrack, art style, and general tone makes me wish I could have known more about Cloudbank and explored the city more.

Thank you Supergiant for this amazing game! After playing it at Day of the Devs back in October I was eagerly awaiting the game's release!

Can't wait to make my way through more of Recursion mode!

reviewText:
If there is one thing I value most in single player games it is atmosphere, and above all else, Transistor has the best atmosphere of any game I have ever played to date. This game is beautiful in every sense of the word. The visuals are stunning with mind-blowing attention to detail. The world is immersive, fascinating, and thought provoking. The audio, oh lord the audio, not only does this game feature my absolute favorite soundtrack of any video game I have ever played, but it fits the ambience in a way that is truly beyond words.
Without giving away anything, the story is intriguing to say the least. It absorbs you from the very beginning and makes you want to keep playing to find out more and more about the world. The characters are equally as interesting and mysterious. The game really makes your imagination run wild.
The gameplay is simple when you want it to be, as well as complex and difficult should you choose. It is almost a turn-based game but not quite. The core mechanics revolve around pausing fights and executing movements and attacks. Very simplistic on paper, but with the amount of customization available with all of the abilities you obtain, it has endless replay potential.
I can honest to goodness give this game a 10/10 rating, the only possible gripe I could have with it is that it wasn’t longer. Without a doubt it is my favorite game.

reviewText:
Transistor, Supergiant Games' second release, is an enthralling, unique experience that meets and shatters any expectation one may have about it. If you've played Bastion, and are wondering how Transistor fares in comparison with it, know that this game pulls all the right inspiration from SPG's previous release, but maintains its own identity to set it apart as something truly original.

Like Bastion, Transistor is a narrative-driven game with emphasis on configurable gameplay, i.e. loadouts. There's optional difficulty modifiers and the game plays in standard psuedo-isometric fashion. But the similarities end there. Unlike Bastion, Transistor's fighting system is much more diverse and complex; more RPG, less action-adventure. A core component of that system is something called 'Turn()' mode, which essentially shifts the game from real-time to turn-based action. I find Transistor's combat system to be incredibly unique, and something that enables multiple play styles to shine through.

The story of the game, while similar to Bastion, in that it's a linear, narrative-driven plot, is again, just superficially similar. While the narrator in Bastion is more so telling a story, the narrator in Transistor isn't really a narrator at all. He's another character, with his own perspective and reactions on what's going on around him. He doesn't really tell the story so much as he does experience it. The real meat of lore is actually acquired through using abilities you've gathered in various ways. This is a vastly different take on storytelling because one may not have even uncovered the whole thing through one playthrough. I believe though, that the game meant to be played like that; it's meant to be played through more than once. And it's obvious, as the New Game+ mode is called a 'Recursion'. For some, this may be a turn off, which is understandable. After my first playthrough, I was left with more questions than answers. It left a slightly sour taste in mouth, but after playing more and uncovering all that there was to be uncovered, I enjoyed the story much more than I initially did. It's a very different way to tell a story, but I think fans will appreciate it.

Overall, I highly recommend Transistor. It has creative, unique gameplay with a story that is equally as intriguing. Not to mention the beautiful art and soundtrack, which is worth buying in its own right!

reviewText:
Transistor is an art-aesthetic game made by the same people behind Bastion, which will give you a good idea of what to expect from the game from a graphical perspective so I won’t waste time on that (except to say that it’s really pretty). As the story goes, you play a rogue vocalist on a quest to find out the meaning behind the mysterious events happening around her. The most important of which involving the accidental death of one of her biggest fans by a sword called the Transistor.

You might think the gameplay is somewhat similar to Bastion and if you were to ignore the Turn() aspect, you would probably be right. However, this is where the game distances itself: at any point during combat, you can stop time and plan your next few moves, in a sequence, to be executed when you press the end turn button. This allows for some significant advantages over certain hardy foes that would normally steamroll you in real-time. Additionally, each of the processes you pick up can be slotted in one of three roes: active (for active-weapon use), upgrade (boosts active weapon), or passive (various passive benefits). This allows for a wide variety of process assignments that really lets you find your own personal combat style. If for some reason, you find the game to be too easy, you can add ‘limiters’ you have earned at any save point to spice things up in exchange for extra experience.

I found the narrator to be a bit sycophantic, almost to the point where I expected him to wear a fedora and use phrases like “m’lady” while rambling about what it is to be “a gentleman” (especially certain parts of the game where he resembled a drunk version of himself with embarrassingly low levels of restraint). Despite all the cringe, the game is pretty fun and a good challenge if you turn on all the limiters and there are some challenge sections that may warrant a replay if you so desire.

My name is Red. I have a sword but it's not a sword, it's a transistor. Don't worry about it, it still kills people. Well, processes mainly, but it killed that guy I liked. I think I liked him? The transistor/sword talks to me. It's the spirit of the dead guy. He rambles on about something that I don't understand and he talks over news articles I'm trying to read. On my quest to avenge the guy I barely know I meet a few other people but I can't understand a word they say. No, wait, subtitles give them a voice. I read all about them in my notes but whoever wrote these bios seemed to leave out some rather important bits, like why I care. Still, the pictures are pretty and after I kill them they mingle with my dead boyfriend(?) on the other side. At least they don't talk to me when their dead.

And so I drag my very heavy transistor/sword through the sectors annihilating everything in my path stopping occassionally to admire the beauty of the fading world and for a bite of sea monster pizza from Junction Jan's only to recurse and do it again, expect this time... no, I still don't know what's going on...

reviewText:
Bastion 2: Electric Boogaloo is a fantastic game, and a more apt name than it should be. That said, while the game has many key similarities to Bastion (art style, certain plot points, music, the same narrator), it also has many key differences, even some more subtle ones in those similarities I mentioned. Most obvious is that it's sci-fi rather than fantasy, the story as a whole is bit more subtle and atmospheric, and the battle system is... turn-based...???

Regardless, it's a ton of fun, the music and art are just as good if not better than the amazing precedent Bastion set, giving us a lot more vocals of the singer behind Build That Wall from Bastion (there's even a hum button this time around! it is the most important button, you can literally have your character hum to the music at pretty much any time), and having a more tech-heavy-feel to it in general.

Point is, it's a fantastic game, buy it 500 times.

reviewText:
Game Name: Transistor
Original Release: 2014
Personal Rating: A
Estimated Playtime:18 Hours
Multiplayer/Coop?: None
Played on: Steam Controller

Transistor is an indie game created from the same makers of Bastion. It is a unique rpg that has an interesting balance between turn-based gameplay and real time gameplay.

Controls: When I played this, I used the Steam Controller. It wasn’t hard to use at all, and it seemed rather natural to use a controller with the game. Joystick seemed prime for the movement option, and the four buttons on the face of the controller worked really well with the four skills that you have to use in-game.

Graphics: This isn’t a Crysis level of graphics. Coming straight out of an indie studio, it seems unique and more like art. Cut-scenes mix in well with the 2.5D gameplay, and it’s easy to figure out what is happening as time goes on.

Music: Much like Bastion, Supergiant Games (the creators) release excellent soundtracks and this is no exception. Between the songs that you unlock and Red’s (the Main Character) humming, you find yourself playing the game for the music instead of the gameplay.

Overall: Transistor has a unique and potent combination of great music, easy controls and compelling gameplay, all within a fun game with an interesting plot. No super strategy is needed as you will eventually figure out the game throughout time. I would recommend it at any price, but it does drop down during the sales.

Transistor is a true beauty among the many available games there are.

As soon as I started the game I wanted to know: What exactly happened here? Who is this woman/main-character we're controlling? Whats up with this sword? I tracked along the streets of the beautiful town to find that out and soon met enemys, trying to stop me.

Getting to know the characters even better would have been nice too, but every game needs to end - And this ending.. was a surprise for me.

reviewText:
Bottom Line: 9/10 Transistor is a fantastic game with a deep combat system, touching story, and merit to stand apart from Supergiant's previous work in Bastion.

I don't usually stay up till 6 AM in the morning to play a game. I've been playing video games for a very long time and usually  I am critical enough of the experience to be able to separate myself from it at a certain point. So I say with full weight behind it, that Transistor was able to captivate me enough to marathon through it for close to 8 hours and beat the game in one night. From the very start, the art direction in this game is truly breathtaking. Audio and visual experience for Transistor is unique and consistent in blowing you away (akin to Bastion). Incorporate such a strong and unique Sci-Fi aesthetic into gameplay that not only is fun but actually has strategic dynamic depth throughout the entire experience; you have a game that you simply cannot miss. On the gameplay front, while you are bound to see plenty of Steam guides for ultimate combos (in addition to finding your own), the move system at very least hooks the player for the whole first play though by steadily giving new moves and possible combinations to cater to the player's strategic curiosity. I will end with what has stuck with me the most throughout these past 24 hours of beating the game; that is the fact that Transistor is able to stand on its own ground apart from Bastion, effectively escaping the downsides of comparisons. Instead, I truly feel Bastion and Transistor are complementary masterstrokes for Supergiant's portfolio of games; not tied by any assumed experiential aspects but rather by the greatness in the games alone.

- V

reviewText:
Supergiant Games' second release is once again defined by its narrative and Logan Cunningham's sexy, sexy voice. Much like Bastion, there's a theme (sort of) of the world broken, and once again you have the key to piecing things back together. Gameplay provides a very well-done array of ways to approach the enemies, and encourages heavy experimentation until you find something you play well with and like.

World design, from art to sound, is once again the shining star in the game. Every detail is gorgeously hand-drawn, every piece of music milking that beautiful neo-noir style for all it's worth. Logan Cunningham's voice work is more expressive and drawing this time around, though every bit as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic as before.

All in all, a truly wondrous game to behold, one of the very few games released these days which truly have a vision behind them. Its only flaw is that there isn't enough of it to last, but still much preferable to a narrative that drags on. Supergiant Games officially has my vote of confidence after two stellar games.

10 outta 10, 100 outta hundred, best game, best game 9/10

reviewText: If you prefer quality over quantity this game is for you. Transistor is a fantastic game with amazing soundtracks that you hear throughout the game. The gameplay itself is quite unique but the best way I could describe it is if you had Dragon Age:Origin's ability to stop time and every move or attack you plan,sucked up this time bar that let you stay in that frozen time and after you unleash your barrage of attacks it would just charge back up read for you to use again. This is pretty crucial to most combat in the game so you'll tend to spam it as soon as it comes off cooldown. The story when you first start is pretty confusing and I pretty much had no idea what was going on until I was done with a 1/3 of the game and the game isn't really straightforward with the storytelling so you pretty much have to go through with the tidbits that are given to you at the beginning and just complete the puzzle by either completing files or going through OVC terminals or just listening to what the characters say during their dialogues. The customization allows you to format abilities you can use during a battle, augment those abilities onto another ability that enhances it in some way, or you can decide to augment it onto your body. You can pretty much switch however way you want it anytime during the game provided you get to a terminal which is pretty common throughout the whole game. I was actually impressed with how the game looked overall and it pretty much looked like a work of art, not counting the gameplay aspects or the phenomenal soundtracks. The replayability is pretty much the same as Bastion and it lets you restart over and is called Recursion, keeping your abilitites and level so you can go through the whole game fighting the same late game enemies you would be fighting at the end of the game. Transistor is short, you could probably finish the whole game in around 10 hours but sweet jesus it's 10 really good hours without even touching the Recursion aspect. Transistor is GOTY material, buy it, try it, cry at how short it is.

reviewText: Transistor blends Bastion’s fast-paced isometric combat with a methodical tactical planning mode to create a unique action system that fits well within its vibrant urban sci-fi setting. You can assign each ability as an action command, a passive bonus, or as an upgrade to another ability, which allows for a vast variety of combinations. This character customization, as well as your options to tweak enemy abilities, provides you significant freedom to tailor your game experience.  Bastion’s combat sandbox and escalating challenge modes return, complementing Transistor’s many avenues for player experimentation. The combat system, however, does significantly favor the planning mode, leaving you relatively weak during the real-time portions while you wait for your planning ability to recharge.  The gorgeous character art and atmospheric music paint a beautiful presentation over the solid gameplay, but the story feels stretched thin as major characters and events receive only minor acknowledgement before moving on. Moreover, the omnipresent narrator says little of value and his comments come across as a scattered stream-of-consciousness in contrast to the wise insight of Bastion’s commentary. Transistor retains many of Bastion’s best elements and distinguishes itself with its unique hybrid action, but fails to entirely match its predecessor’s heights.\n\n4/5 – Really liked it.

reviewText:
Sometimes, after playing a lot of competitive multiplayer games, you just have to step back and enjoy something much more authentic like Transistor. This game allowed me to really appreciate a story based single-player game as I was drowned in a breathtaking world with its own unique atmosphere and gameplay.

During my first few minutes in to the game, I instantly recognized the amount of work Super Giant Games put into Transistor's presentation. The visual aspect of the game consists of beautiful hand drawn art, a vibrant colour scheme, smooth animation, and excellent character design. The auditory aspect is also just as outstanding as the visuals; the soundtracks consists of a mix of haunting guitar rifts and electronic music which captures the mood of the empty and haunting city of Cloudbank, and the voices and sound effects are also on par with this.

The gameplay is also unique and makes the game more strategic compared to Super Giant's previous game, Bastion. The turn system allows you to plan your attacks, but there's also a mix of mechanical play with this, such as having to decide the best times to switch to turn mode or real time. I also really enjoyed how the functions worked (which are the skills), as there are thousands of possible combinations as you can use, since you can either use the function as an active, a passive, or you can stack the function on another function to add a unique property. I also liked how they added limiters in the game to make the game much more challenging in a unique way that rewards the player.

reviewText:
Transistor is a game that drives my heart into the world of cyberpunk and dystopian science fiction. It’s not just about gorgeous presentation and addictive combat, but I also realize the fault of human creation.

The more you advance in Transistor, the more you understand how the truth of the Cloudbank. Most of the time, Transistor is your main weapon and storyteller. Transistor also gives you strong narrative, telling what is going on, and comments on your interaction even each terminal is worthwhile to read.

As you fight against The Process, the main feature is shined out. Transistor’s combat can split into real-time approach and turn-based approach which give you planning phase to set your position, target, and set of skills. The variety of skill as you progress through the game make Transistor has unique combat and gives player’s choice to try out their own skill build. Even the limiter feature which works like player debuff, and test rooms offer challenge and thinking rather than spamming for win. However, it can be frustrated for cool down after turn mode is used as you may have to run around in small area while some enemies can constantly harm you. It is just minor issue which you can get over with once you get your perfect build.

Transistor is such a unique and great experience. Not just engaging combat, but I fell in love in polished art design, story, and memorable soundtracks which create what people like in the game. And I’m pretty sure you will enjoy much as I do once you get deeper into The Cloudbank.
