reviewText:
I have ambivalent feelings about Transistor. As much as I love the overall aesthetic and atmosphere of the game, I could not get into the combat at all. Unlike Bastion (which was developed by the same company), Transistor suffers from somewhat repetitive combat while enemies lack variety.

Whereas Bastion was more action oriented, Transistor puts emphasis on planning and requires you to pause the battle – i.e. initiate a Turn() –  and queue up your attacks, execute those attacks, and then spend some time running away from enemies during Turn() recovery, until you are able to repeat the process. You wield only one weapon (the sword Transistor) augmented with various functions: you can have up to four functions installed at a time and each can be upgraded with up to two other functions. You can change your functions at every access point (which are save points in the game and are quite frequent) but mostly you find a combination that works and stick with it – since enemies are not very varied, you don't need to change your strategy much between different battles. As a result, the combat starts feeling repetitive.

Another thing that doesn't work as good in Transistor as it did in Bastion is the narrator. In Bastion he was an omniscient narrator who recounted the protagonist's adventures and described the post-apocalyptic world the game was set in. In Transistor, the narrator is the voice of the protagonist's lover trapped in the sword and his comments are directed at her – and frequently they are reduced to inconsequential passing comments, small talk, comments on whether you've entered some door or what the weather is like and similar. The developers clearly wanted a narrator to accompany you on your journey, but too often he is reduced to just making passing remarks that are in no way necessary, illuminating, witty, etc. As a result, many of his remarks feel superfluous and unneeded. On a second playthrough he becomes downright annoying at moments.

The narrator would have worked a lot better if only the developers allowed him to talk more about what was happening in the game, about the motives of the antagonists, about past events that took place, about the world of Cloudbank in general. But they made the story purposefully vague, so that you have to uncover it by reading the terminals and the descriptions of the functions, which begs the question – why have a narrator at all?

I wanted to like Transistor much more than I did because the art design and the atmosphere of the game instantly attracted me. The game is absolutely gorgeous looking and at every step I wanted to see more of that world. The story also drew me in right at the start – it started as a murder mystery and I needed to piece together what happened and why, and where my character was even going. A lot of the story is told through terminals you can interact with and through the descriptions of functions, which are not available until you have equipped a function in three slots (active, passive, and upgrade) and used it. However, much is also left unexplained or at least ambiguous, and I'm not sure if this was done on purpose or if it is the result of the fact that not everything can be delivered adequately through terminals and function descriptions.

Despite some of its flaws, Transistor is an interesting game. I just wish I found the combat more fun.

This game was amazing! I picked it up because I enjoyed Bastion so much. Its similar to Bastion in that its the same narrator (hell yes), the music (Darren Korb) its got your side challenge missions, the plus playthrough but its so much more. Cons

reviewText:
This game is a work of art. It has been quite some time since I last played a game that was so capitivating or moving.

For what it's worth, I have never played Bastion so I won't be able to compare Transistor to it. That said, the game's aesthetics are astounding, both in terms of sights and sounds. The game's story is also very good. It essentially dumps you into the middle of events and you have to unpack it from there, tying most of it up at the end. The game's gameplay is also tied into the narrative in a nice and tight manner. The game mechanics involve using various modules that can be equipped either in active, passive, or upgraded slots. The game encourages experimentation as each module contains lore involving a particular character that can only be unlocked by using it in each of these slots. It incentivizes player experimentation in a keen way, rather than finding one tried-and-true attack. Additionally, if your health depletes in a battle it doesn't seem to outright fail you (at least as far as I've experienced). Instead, it disables one of your abilities and recharges your health. As Two Best Friends put it, it's essentially telling you that whatever you're doing currently isn't working. It's another incentive to experiment.

We're only halfway through the year, but this might honestly get my choice as the best game of 2014. I look forward to the replays ahead of me.

UPDATE 06/28

So I thought about this game some more and I want to add another reason why I like this game so much: Red seems like an actual, living person.

This is done masterfully through small things in the story. The two that stand out for me are the fact that we see her eat pizza and we see her go to use a bathroom. And I mean use *use* a bathroom, not like Silent Hill *use* a bathroom where you stick your arm down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to pull out a wallet. We see her walk into a bathroom, a fade to black with a flush, and the game returns.

This was endearing to me. Emotions and whatnot go a long way into making a fictional character appear human, but I honestly think it's the small minutiae that ultimately make fictional characters pop to life more. It's not as exciting as drama, but to me it pulses with the true blood of life: the banality of existence. I apprecaited it a lot.

reviewText:
This game is just too pretentious. While the style, both ins visuals and audio, is excellent,the game tries to do too much, and just doesn't succeed.

The plot is intentionally obscure - in the beginning the player has exactly no idea who's who, where is the plot happening and what are the rules of the world. While the majority of these things are revealed eventually, the player still spends more than half of the game acting without any understanding of what's happening around him, and the eventual revealations just  don't have the emotional significance to justify past obscurity.

Beyond that, the fighting mechanism is novel on paper, but tedious in execution. The player spends half of the time in combat unable to do anything, and the visual obscure such information as where are enemies facing and whether or not certain shots will hit or not.

The bottom line is an experience which feels like it should amount to a lot of fun, but doesn't really hit the mark it set for itself.

reviewText:
The main problem with Transistor is that it's almost, but not entirely, completely unlike Bastion.  The story is intriguing, the setting is enticing, and the combat is incredibly customizable, but every so often, I was struck by how similar to something in Bastion part of the game felt.  Supergiant did a good job distancing themselves from the ideas they had from their first game for the most part yet certain plot points and game aspects, like the narrator responding to the little things you do and telling the story that way made Transistor feel not quite as fresh as it could have been.  The similar art style and same voice actors certainly didn't help, but Supergiant is a small company, so that's understandable.  Besides, the game does look incredible.

I want to mention the combat again, because it's stellar.  You enter a planning phase, stringing together attacks and movements and then executing them super fast in real time.  Afterwards, you have to dodge enemies' attacks and survive until you can enter your planning phase again.  I'm sure that's not unique, but the fact that your combat abilities are made up of various Functions(), each of which can serve as a primary attack, a secondary modifier, or a passive buff ability, allows you to modify your skill set in an unimaginable variety of ways.  You're even rewarded for switching up your playstyle, since using different Functions() in different ways unlocks backstory about aspects of the world.

The enemies are refreshing, too, especially when they start to unlock more powerful abilities.  Fetch can go ♥♥♥♥ itself, though.  Those things is super overpowered and I hate fighting them.

reviewText:
This game was an incredible experience. It played naturally, had just the right amount of challenge, and tells a beautiful and dark story in a beautiful and dark way.

Its major flaw is simply being too short. It feels like 2 acts of a 3-act game. It was really not until the credits rolled up the screen that I realized that there was no third act, that the boss was indeed the final one, and that there was nothing left to be done.

Why they made this decision, I do not know. This game could have been even more - gone even more deeply into a story more compelling than almost any other. But it was cut short, and that is tragic to see.

9/10

reviewText:
The system for combining and modifying attacks really makes this game special. By allowing the player to respec at every checkpoint, the game allows the player to experiment with this system, which is complex and nuanced enough to give satisfying rewards to experimentation. The best combination I've found so far is void() with purge() and crash() as an opening attack. Limiting the total slots available for attacks forces tradeoffs and compromises that make the process of building and rebuilding Red's skill set continually interesting.

I've finished one playthrough in about 6 hours completing a fair number of the optional test levels. I'm looking forward to playing a new game with more skills unlocked to allow for more experimentation.

The story is mysterious, but enough hints are provided to make it intriguing. The relationship between Red and the Transistor really carries the game, although it doesn't immediately develop.

The ability to pause time is a nice inclusion because it allows for a slower, strategic playstyle. I used it for nearly every encounter. Waiting for the cooldown is a drag, but the game thoughtfully allows the player to make tradeoffs to mitigate the cooldown.

Lastly, the music and art style are beautifully atmospheric, and I found the voice work solid.

reviewText:
Transistor is a fantastic game: great music, great visuals, great gameplay, and an interesting story.

This one hit all the sweet spots, in my opinion. Good length, too - each play through (and it's very much worth recursing/game+'ing the game once) takes about 10 hours.

Now, if you're looking for another Bastion, then you may be disappointed. Most of Transistor's combat takes place in a  turn-based mode, where you plan out your movement/attacks, then execute your plan and watch it play out. You can fight in real time (and some of the challenge trials are actually easier this way), but for the most part you'll end up taking too much damage and/or getting knocked out of your attacks to make it a very useful way to play.

Difficulty is great, in that it scales wonderfully. By default, you'll have a fairly easy time killing the Process. However, there are 10 limiters that you can choose, which will make the Process stronger, in exchange for faster leveling up. I can honestly tell you that running with all 10 limiters will make for a very harrowing experience.

Again, as I mentioned, you should totally play at least twice - first time around gives a good experience, but the second time around - when both you and the Process are leveled up, and you can start stacking functions for extra-brokeness and fun, is what really makes the game.

Final word - this is the only game that I've gone out of my way to get 100% of the achievements.

reviewText:
This game's sountrack is a melodic warm embrace upon your eardrums and inner soul.

I'm on my second playthrough. Before I begin rambling, here's a quick list:

1. This game is short, I probably finished my first playthrough in about 10 hours or so.
2. Get the soundtrack, you will not regret it.
3. This game is stunningly beautiful, and if you liked Bastion at all, you'll love this, possibly even more.
4. The gameplay element to this is fascinating. You can, much like in Bastion, configure and reconfigure your protagonist as you please, taking her attacks apart and putting them back together again just like with sexy, exploding Lego's.
5. The further you progress through the story the more upgrades and limiters you will choose to unlock.
6. Limiters can be brutal (I turned 9 on immediately on my second run-through, thinking I was a boss with the NG+ system (New Game+) - No. I was wrong. I was hilariously wrong.
7. I've heard the first ending isn't really the ending. I would not be surprised.
8. The pace of the game is very quick, and the only distraction from the story are little rooms you can find to practice different setups and complete challenges. The first ones are easy, but on towards the end of the game the last two stability tests were rather challenging. This game makes you strategize sometimes ;P
9. Again, this is one of those games this is more about pleasing your senses. Just let it happen.
10. I would suggesting searching on Youtube the following tracks, and listening to them in this order:
> Gateless
> We All Become Instrumental
> The Spine
> Vanishing Point Hummed (sounds just like a theme from arguably one of the greatest games of all time and space)
> In Circles

Seriously. Grand game. SO glad I got it on sale so I could buy the OST as well for the grand total of $10 and some change. Which I then used a gift card for X3

reviewText:
Transistor.
A work of art.
In every possible way.

Honestly i would find it a good enough reason to buy this game for the soundtrack alone. It is one of the most amazing OST's i've ever heard.

Consequently, Transistor is a visual and musical extravagance and is worth every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ penny you can throw at your screen. And if it's on sale...you really have no excuse...
Transistor is a must play!

reviewText:
6/10

This game was made by the makers of Bastion, so I had my hopes up. Sadly, while the graphic style and music is gorgeous, the story and gameplay are lacking cohesion. Similar to Bastion the action is controlled from isometric view and has lots of action rpg elements.

There is real time combat and a turn mode, which stops the action and allows you to plan moves, which are then executed. Combat in real time is clunky, as the enemies move much to fast to evade, which forces the player into the turn mode. Consequently the game forces hit and run tactics. Stop the action, move close to the enemy, hit him with a few spells and run out of range. Rinse and repeat.

One of the few good things about combat is the endless combinations of skills you can use. Each of the skills can be used as primary or enhancer of another skill. Sadly, you will end up using the 1-3 heavy hitting spells, without ever experimenting too much.

All in all the developers did not succeed making this a cohesive game. Graphics and sound are great, gameplay and story telling are lacking. So you find yourself walking down pretty hallways without ever caring about the enemies you kill or knowing what exactly happened in this dystopian world.

reviewText: Beautifully executed game. Combines a 1920s theme and a future technology theme that blend together almost perfectly, and is can be seen throughout the game in the numerous splash artworks that are found as you go. The combat system in the game is well done, and the various abilities and combinations allow for different types of gameplay. It's somewhat of a real-time, yet turn-based method, where you can basically stop time to plan out your attacks. Once you have completed attacking, you must survive the next few seconds until you have a chance to stop time again. The storyline itself is understood as a love story from the beginning, with a tragic end. The music in the game is atmospheric and soothing, and the soft, muffled humming that can be heard in-between turns is possibly my favorite part of the game. I'm hope that they will release a Transistor announcer for Dota 2, because the Transistor's voice is sublime.\n\n10/10, would recommend to anyone.

column25:
Transistor brings about a new combat system that has been done before, but never quite as well-implemented as it was in Transistor. You can play the game like it's Diablo, sure- but this is incredibly dangerous, difficult, and most of the time, uneffective. The game also features a Planning phase, in which the character is able to move freely about in a frozen world, planning their movements and attacks. Very turn-based in style. Along with this unique combat system, Transistor features countless upgrades, many difficulty mutators in the style of the Shrine from Bastion, and the ability to string attacks together for devastating results.

All in all, I may be a bit biased towards Transistor, as Bastion is arguably one of the best games I've ever played, but I without a doubt recommend this game. The $20 pricetag stirred me up a bit at first, but I can guarantee that it was worth it. Transistor is definitely an unforgettable experience that I cannot recommend you to buy enough.
And while you're at it, buy Bastion. You won't regret it.

Despite the obvious flaws that the game has, (bugs, crashes, framerate issues) the game is carried by the weight of the story alone. The only thing that truly saddened me with Transistor was the mere fact that I didn't have more time to spend in Red's world. Without a doubt, I would recommened this game to anyone that cares for a story in video games. For anyone that claims that a video game can never truly be a work of art, this would be my go to game to show them.

reviewText:
On its own, Transistor is a solid game with a great atmosphere and world, a very complicated and interesting story, and a very unique combat system. The game features narration by Logan Cunningham, who plays a voice trapped in the Transistor, leading to a lot of real-time commentary on your actions. It's odd but the terms 'action' and 'turn based' simultaneously need to be used to describe the game. The music as well is really good, and is a prominent element to the game.

This is SuperGiant's second game, their first being Bastion (a must-play, btw). For those who HAVE played Bastion, it'll feel relatively familiar in many respects (such as how the story progresses, Jen Zee's artstyle, etc.), but still unique. Comparatively, both games featured Cunningham as a narrator, though IMO it worked a bit better for Bastion as he was more able to tell a story, almost omnipotent, rather than act as a lone character. This is probably part of why the story is a bit confusing for Transistor.

While Bastion's strong point was its narration, where Transistor really excels is its combat system. As I've said, the combat system is very unique. It's a little hard to understand at first but it is incredibly deep and challenging, with multiple setups, perks, and moves that are all balanced very well. The only weak part is the interface used to synergize the skills: it's just as deep and complex as the fighting itself. A slightly clearer interface would greatly help, but you can also overcome this by just gradually memorizing the functions of the skills for when they're applied.

Unfortunately a lot of the additional story elements are in the form of text-based profiles from traces and skills you've acquired, and while it expands the world, setting the time aside to read through the logs for each trace you acquire kinda feels tedious. That said, there's enough explained in the main storyline to understand the world as much as you need to (if you're paying attention), so the logs are more just for additional sustenance. The game also lacks some kind of central world hub: the one they have available is only available at certain times in the middle of missions, rather than a place you return to after each mission. There are some challenge modes available for additional content, and they're worth doing, though I personally am hoping SuperGiant will add in more challenge modes in the future.

The main storyline isn't too long, will take about 6-8 hours to beat, but it's very rich and fulfilling, and leaves a New Game+ option to experience more of the combat, with a few subtle changes to the story. Overall a worthy second title out of SuperGiant Games.

reviewText:
Only tossers write lengthy steam reviews so here's a quick list of the reasons you should buy this game.

Playstyle is fluid: You get a bunch of abilities, four of which you can slot. The rest of your remaining abilities can be used to augment the slotted abilities, giving bonus effects or changing the ability altogether. You can swap them around, mix and match and change them as much as you want, to find a playstyle that suits you or just to experiment with new ways to play after every fight, keeping things fresh.

Art style is beautiful: The city looks amazing and intricate. The cutscenes are minimalistic but still amazingly illustrated. It's a very pretty game to look at.

Setting is cool: Futuristic, yet original. It's a city where everything is done by the numbers, to the point where even the sky is painted and the weather is voted on by the residents.  It feels three dimensional.

Story is interesting: It's a game that tells you nothing, but leaves tidbits here and there for you to read so you can put together the bigger picture yourself. It's a little frustrating at times but it keeps you wanting more.

The music is incredible: When people hark on about a game soundtrack, I usually dismiss it. How memorable can some background music be? Transistor's answer: Phenominal. It fits the game and setting, and like the art style, experiencing it is an absolute pleasure. I've never heard a soundtrack like this before.

Short answer: Buy this game. It's bloody good.

reviewText:
In a world where Tron meets Fritz Lang's Metropolis, there is a singer who has lost her voice wielding a sword who just found one - the eponymous Transistor. Together they battle a digital menace called The Process in order to...
Well, what do they want to achieve actually? See, Transistor provides two challenges for the player: first, fighting The Process and second, actually understanding what is going on. While some people will hate this minimum style story telling, others will embrace it as another challenge to overcome and will find it very compelling.

Combat, on the other hand, is much more straightforward, deeply strategic and very rewarding. You gain a number of abilities, each of which may be used by itself as an active attack, as support for another ability or as a passive enhancement to your character. Take Bounce, for example. By itself it is an attack that ricochets off enemies, hitting multiple targets in the process. Add it as support to another ability and now this attack will chain-hit. Assign it as a passive enhancement and it will make enemy attacks bounce off of you. Decisions, decisions...
Adding to that is the Turn() sequence, which allows you to pause the game, queue up attacks and actions, and have them executed in bullet-time. Thus, strategy is much more important than good reflexes.

Most important about Transistor, however, is that it is art. Not art as in the you might lable this as pre-post-retro modernism" sense. It's art because it's beautiful in every aspect. There is a fundamental aesthetic vision that permeates all elements of the game and strings them together nicely. It just works
date: and it's gorgeous all the time.\n\nThat being said
recommended: not everything is perfect about Transistor. Gameplay generally feels just a little bit rough. Menus like ability selection are somewhat clunky and Turn() can be hit-or-miss without much explanation. The key mechanic for getting more background info becomes somewhat tedious after novelty wears off
hoursPlayed: paling significantly in contrast to the Turn() mechanic. Some streamlining might have done wonders

reviewText:
Transistor is the second game from Bastion developer Super Giant Games, and it is another exceptionally crafted artistic RPG.

In Transistor you play the role of Red, a beautiful and talented musician who has seemingly lost her voice.  The game begins with Red pulling a sword like device known as the Transistor out of the chest of a dead man.  Immediately the Transistor begins talking to Red as if it knows her.  The voice of the Transistor is how we learn what's going on in this abandoned ghost town of a city called Cloudbank.   Much like the narrator in Bastion comments on the situation of Caelondia, the Transistor will talk to Red about things happening in Cloudbank.  It seems Super Giant Games really has a thing for mysterious apocalyptic events that wipe out flourishing cities.

Not only is the Transistor your talking guide through the game it's also a very powerful tool and weapon.   In the beginning the Transistor only has two functions loaded into it, thus giving you two different attack options.  As you level up you'll unlock   more functions, function upgrade slots, and passive function slots.  The function customization and use is incredibly deep and fun to experiment with as you explore combinations to fit your play style.  It really makes the combat an enjoyable sandbox of trial by fire.

Every function in the game has 3 optional ways of using it in the Transistor.  The first use is an Active attack and used to directly afflict damage or other debuffs on the enemies.   The second use is an upgrade slot to an existing Active attack.  This will add extra abilities to your attacks.   The final use is a passive slot which will grant you various buffs or abilities that are always active.  With 16 different functions to unlock, and each having 3 ways to potentially use them, you can see the amount of customization gets exponential.  And even more in new game plus when it allows you to unlock another copy of an already used function.

Using the functions in the variety of ways will also reward the story loving fanatics.  Each function you discover is linked to one pronounced citizen of Cloudbank, and as you use the functions in combat you'll unlock background information regarding their history.  It's a fun way to learn more about the story and reward players for trying new combinations of function loadouts.

While the story of Transistor may seem eerily similar to Bastion the combat game play is quite different.  Arguably Transistor can be played in the same real time hack-n-slash style of Bastion, but in all likelihood you'll be using the strategic pause mode for most battles.  This mode feels like a turn based strategy game.   When combat is paused you are shown a progress bar of action points to spend.  Every movement, every function will use up action points until the bar is full.   This allows you to plan out your attack before committing to the plan.  Once you execute a plan you'll see all your attacks played out in real time.  You'll then need to fight in real time as you wait for the cool down timer on strategic mode.  It really is a good balance of real time and turn based combat.

The thing I loved most about Bastion was it's story, soundtrack and art direction, and once again with Transistor they delivered.   A hauntingly desolate city again brought to life by beautiful landscapes and enchanting music you'll be humming along the way with Red.

While it may be relatively short it has replay value in new game plus, just to try more function combos.  If you enjoyed Bastion then you'll find Transistor worthy of a play.

reviewText:
I loved Bastion and I love this game even more.

The narrative style is different but still present. The sound track is just as excellent as Bastion's if not more so. The art style is different but just as good. Everything you liked about Bastion is there and just as good, but different.

Except the combat. The actual combat itself is brilliant and rewarding, with thousands of possible ability permutations and lacking the feeling that any one combination beats out the others. All the abilities are useful, all of them fun, and all of them let you tackle each fight in a variety of interesting ways.

Some people have complained about the combat in this game, but their complaints are quite bluntly bewildering to me. While it does get increasingly challenging, and dying can be frustrating, I never had to redo any one fight more than twice, and the game autosaves often.

I have not enjoyed a game this much in a very long time. It is exciting to even talk about. This is Game of the Year - or at the very least the Indie Game of the Year.

For $20 you get around 9 hours of singleplayer content that is brilliantly designed, written, and narrated.

reviewText:
Bastion is an easy and accurate point of comparison for Transistor; if you like one, you'll probably like the other. But the gameplay here is a lot deeper and richer, so it's worth a look even if you didn't care for Supergiant's previous effort.

Similar to Bastion, the story is simple but beautifully presented. The futuristic/maybe-computerized city of Cloudbank is a visually lush setting for monster bashing, and the snippets you find and decipher throughout the game paint a unique portrait of the city's history and the villain's motivations. It's easy to get drawn in, even if, from a player's perspective, you're just running around murdering everything in your path.

It probably helps that your rampaging is so enjoyable. Combat is real-time, but you can periodically freeze time to cue up a string of commands as if it were turn-based. That combined with the incredibly flexible system of combining your power-ups into increasingly elaborate attacks opens up a tremendous number of options, both on-the-fly and in terms of your overall playstyle. Want to kite around and chip away at range? You can spec for that. Want to play fully real-time as a bruiser? Sure. Want to mind control everyone into killing each other? Go for it. Run around unleashing monster turn-based combos whenever you can? Yessir.

If anything, the biggest problem is that the mechanics are SO flexible that it gets daunting. Thankfully, there are a handful of mechanics that guide you towards new combinations (avoiding the Diablo 3 here is a new option that you have no reason to care about" issue) and
recommended: the game's difficulty is rather forgiving but has options for you to increase it on the fly.\n\nBut bottom line

reviewText: Another good game from Bastion creators Supergiant. Not without flaws though, and not up to the high bar the group set previously with Bastion. Combat is weighted too heavily on use of Turn() movements, and it is straight up impossible to beat the game in only real time combat, unlike what Supergiant said during events like PAX. The game is far more linear than it should be, with almost no splitting off. Additionally, you are given a lot of customization with how you use your skills, but it will always boil down to what does the most burst damage at the time, since you can only effectively fight in Turn(). As such, it has very little replayability, since there is not going to be any variance in order of area completion or how you play the game, unlike Bastion. Lastly, enemies to far, far too much damage, the other reason open combat outside of Turn() isn't feasible. After the halfway point of game, most enemies will take well over half your HP in one attack or combo, and the AI is exceptionally aggressive and tracks movement during thier shots.\n\nDespite all this negatively, the game is still good. Art style is great, story is unusual but interesting, music is solid (though personally find it inferior to Bastion's western styling) and gameplay is mostly enjoyable. It may not be exceptional, but it's still above the average of most AAA releases these days.

reviewText:
4/4 thumbs up

Transistor is the second game from SuperGiant Games, the makers of Bastion, and it shares much in common with their first game.  First, the visuals are quite stunning and appealing.  Second, the narration is excellent.  Third, the protagonist is mute.  Fourth, the story is always compelling you forward.  Last, the story is, sadly, on the short side (around 6 hours if you skip the optional trials), but it's still an excellent story; I'd much rather an amazing, compelling short game than a longer game that loses its direction, or my interest, along the way.  In addition to all of that, the game includes an excellent combat system and the voice acting overall is very well-done, and kudos to SuperGiant Games for doing what much larger studios fail at accomplishing - NPCs that drive the plot forward while talking just the right amount in well-acted voices.

The story puts you in the role of Red, a singer who has lost her voice and wields The Transistor, a talking circuit sword.  Much like Bastion, its predecessor, you travel around the world battling bad guys while trying to figure out what happened and how to stop it.

While fighting The Process, you get the pleasure of enjoying the battle system, which is quite well-done.

First, you may have up to four abilities hotkeyed to your active ability bar.  Each ability has one power-up slot, which can be used to make the ability more powerful in various ways depending on which power-up ability you choose.  As you level up, you unlock more abilities, more power-up slots, and more passive slots.  You can then take all of the abilities you have at your disposal and mix and match them in a myriad of ways to make a style that is both fun for you and powerful enough to get the job done.  Your choices are only limited by the abilities you choose to unlock and how much memory you have available (which can also be increased as you level).

Second, during combat you have the option of real-time or strategic combat.  You can run around the screen using your abilities live as they come off cooldown if that's your thing, or if the combat is especially easy, or you can choose to enter strategic combat and plan out an effective attack sequence and aim your abilities in the most advantageous ways.  However, the strategic combat option has a cooldown every time you use it, during which many of your abilities will be unavailable, so in between strategic rounds you'll need to become adept at evasion.

Last, if you find things too easy, you will unlock limiters as you level.  You can activate these limiters to make combat more difficult, and also to earn more XP from each battle.

If you enjoy RPGs, action-adventure, mystery, and/or strategic combat, then you have a reason to play this game, because it delivers all four in a well-balanced mix.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a game that sets a mood, lets you escape, and has simple but challenging gameplay, you've found it.  If you're familiar with Bastion, you are likely to recognize Supergiant's atmospheric touch in this game.  This game is shorter and has a less fleshed out plot.  Like Bastion, mysteries are left to your imagination, unanswered.  However, the brevity of this game will leave you wishing there were more mysteries to boggle over.

The combat is moderately strategic.  If your mood is too specific, you might be disappointed, whether you're looking for simple combat or serious strategy.  It has more of a balance between simplicity and strategy. It's fun for what it is.

Replay value is mildly elevated by the New Game+ style recursion mode.

Overall, I'd recommend this game.

Pros:
-The music and other atmospheric elements are exceptional.  Supergiant sets a high standard for game atmosphere.
-The main gameplay mechanic is fun and allows for experimentation with the various function (skill/upgrade) combos.

Cons:
-As stated above, the game is shorter than I'd like (needs more plot points).

reviewText:
Transistor is an original, intelligent and lucid action RPG.

The game revolves around Red, a singer whose voice was stolen by the Camerata, a group of individuals determined to Process a city that serves its people. Without formally identifying or constructing her as so, Red is presented as a strong female protagonist; this means she is without any of the clichés that so often inhibit this archetype. Supergiant masterfully pulls off a plot that gives her agency and the ability to sculpt a world inhabited by a cast of colourful characters whom the player learns about through the Functions() of the Transistor. The diversity of the characters, in particular, is to be commended: there are black and mixed-race, gay, lesbian and transgender characters.

The Function() system is at the heart of the game; it allows the player to combine different attacks and abilities in either primary, upgrade, or passive slots, resulting in a unique experience with approximately 22bn different combinations to be had. The system encourages experimentation, and so leads the player in to a kind of exasperating perfectionism: you want to get your loudout exactly right. The mix of frantic, fast-paced real time action and the suspended realm that Turn() provides to plan a sequence of moves is something quite unique and, surprisingly, it doesn't get tiresome. The enemies are varied enough to keep the battles interesting; they regularly upgrade themselves to match your own increasing prowess and there are enough different kinds to always provide a challenge.

The soundtrack is both touching and transcendental; it encapsulates the changing pace of the game, from the arid mystery of a deserted Cloudbank at the beginning to the decaying ruins of a Processed world at the end. The mixture of electronica-esque synths, ambient Portal-like sounds and well-timed guitar riffs give suitable gravitas at just the correct moments. The music feels alive; it actively changes as you switch between states and the Turn() mode.

It's the little things in Transistor that really complete it. Flavour text is what drives the realism and the allusions to software and programming are delightful to see. The different chapters of the plot and the scenes are strung together well enough so the entire game flows. Romanticised additions like the motorbike and the posters add a sense of fun  to the game and an importance to the role that Red has.

The most striking element of the game is probably the artwork; the visuals are stunning and utilise different hues, colours, art styles and changes in lighting to illuminate Cloudbank. Cloudbank is a city inside a computer, but it feels very much real. The nuanced dichotomy of an organic, breathing world that is seen through the window of Red and the basic binary foundation that underlies the entire premise is linked delicately with endless, gorgeous pieces of artwork and cutscenes and this is remarkable.

What makes Transistor a gem is the seamless integration of the idiosyncratic creativity of these elements -- music, artwork, plot and mechanics -- that would only be expected to find in the most successful of indie games, with the overall polish that usually only blockbuster games can pull off. The entire game has a glistening shine that suceeds in being both immersive and compelling, pulling the player into the digital utopia of Cloudbank and refusing to let them go. Certainly a niche game, but it can't be recommended enough.

reviewText:
Transistor uses a simple, but fantastically deep combat system that is sure to indulge fans of customization and optional difficulty. Enemies are varied and interesting, each having a different optimal strategy to be defeated without feeling like a gimmick, and the tactical dimension of combat added by the Turn() system is not to be underestimated.

The game-world of Transistor and atmosphere are exquisite, not the least because of the stunning visuals and bold sound track. The city of Cloudbank is beautiful and feels alive and ripe for exploration. My only complaints lie in the delivery of the game's plot line: Transistor errs a little too heavily on the side of the player filling in the blanks. While I love deducing things about a game's greater environment, the primary plot occasionally required a lot of out-of-game legwork to just feel coherent.

All in all, I would certainly recommend Transistor. It's a delight to play and explore, and a very worthy successor to Bastion.

reviewText:
First, I'll do the quick one: If you liked Bastion, just buy this and go. The story and music may not be as good, but the art and gameplay are even better somehow. Go go go.

For everyone else: Transistor is an absolute blast. The mix-and-match nature of the combat system leads to all sorts of fun experimentation. The semi-turn-based nature is also unlike anything I've never played before, and that alone makes this game worth trying out. It takes a bit for things to really open up, as you have very few powers for the opening bits of the game. But once you've got a sizable arsenal, this game shines like a diamond.

The setting and story are delightfully unusual, but immediately familiar to anyone who enjoyed Tron or Reboot. Supergiant still knows how to make a wonderful soundtrack, and Logan Cunningham is a welcome return as the voice of the eponymous Transistor.

So what's not so great? The back quarter of the game does drag a little bit, and if you want more info on the world than what the story offers you, prepare to do an awful lot of reading of people's bios in menus. And while the general storyline and ending are fine, they do leave a lot up to guesswork and interpretation. That's not to say it's too complex, just that I was left wanting to know a bit more.

Twenty bucks may be a bit high for some, as the game can be beaten in a few sittings. On the other hand, it also means the game is very tight. There's little wasted space, and there is a new game+" feature if you're just not done once you're done. I highly

recommended: even if action games aren't normally you're thing. The combat is very adjustable to be as forgiving or brutally punishing as you like

reviewText:
I really like this game. The music is beautiful, as are the visuals. The voice acting is nice, tho there are some weird pauses between lines. I sometimes find myself waiting for the second half of a sentence that never comes, or thinking a line is done and then it continues a few seconds later. A little weird. But the quality is very high. And I love that sword guy's voice ;oP

The combat system is enjoyable. Lots and lots of options to play with. You have a number of skills that can be either used as a primary skill (like hit 'em with the sword, or shoot a bolt of energy at a distant foe), or they can be slotted into a different primary (like add damage, or AoE to some other skill), or they can be used to provide a more general buff (you have a damage shield, or all backstabs do more damage). That's really clever, and it is surprisingly intuitive to use. I'm a huge fan of the pause-time-and-queue-up-your-actions mechanic as well.

I'd highly recommend it, if you're into RPGs.

reviewText: Transistor is an audio-visual masterpiece. Even if were to lack the the intriguing gameplay and narrative, I would still have loved this game sheerly for its look-and-feel. The art is just so good; I have never taken so many screenshots! The gameplay is fittingly unique: You obtain Functions, which can behave as an active skill, as an upgrade to another skill, or as a passive upgrade. Each Function is derived from a character in the narrative, and to learn all there is to learn about that person, you need to use the Function in all three ways. It encourages experimentation with the mechanics, which can bring surprising results, even if you've settled on a favourite combo. The narrative, subtle and minimalistic, is frankly heart-warming. The world building is outstanding, and I often found myself wanting to rent an apartment in High Rise. The narration doesn't work quite as well as it did in Bastion, but there's just so much more to this game to be bothered by it. Clocking in at around 8 hours for me, Transistor is a fine gaming experience that doesn't overstay its welcome. Protagonist Red may have lost her voice, but the game still spoke to me in a profound way.

I don't want to comment on the story as I could give something away. The game doesn't have a tutorial but it's not really a problem/disadvantage. As you progress & level up you can choose abilities also known as functions that have an active, upgrade & passive ability depending on how you equip these functions as well as combining with other functions provides a big pool of experimental fun. My first playthrough took about 17 hours (your mileage may vary), most of it was experimenting with the functions, but on my second playthrough, which is new game plus was actually more fun than the first time because you carry over the functions from your first playthrough as well as re-earning duplicate functions which increases the gameplay/strategy element even further. You could obtain all the Steam achievement on two playthroughs if you an achievement achiever.

reviewText:
10 out of heart-ing 10.

A game with a great mix of actions and tactical gameplay. Best part is: it never lets up. The whole Functions (abilities) system is diverse and leaves many different options with many different playstyles to be made—where abilities can be used as they are, or used to augment other abilities, or even augment your character. It's all reaaaaally well done.

The music will take you over and force delightful milk out your ears. Get your happy tissues ready. Highly recommend purchasing the soundtrack if you're ever in need of revitalizing.

The art portrays the world both as it is and as it once was—with such beauty. The controls are incredibly good, and I got the strong desire to play the NG+.

Just such a worthy purchase.

EDIT (10/15/2014): Played the NG+ and it was great. It gave me far more room to improve on various skill synergies and properly prepare for a speedrun, which I ended up doing upon completion of NG+. Still just a 10/10 <3

reviewText:
Transistor is a fantastic game: great music, great visuals, great gameplay, and an interesting story.

This one hit all the sweet spots, in my opinion. Good length, too - each play through (and it's very much worth recursing/game+'ing the game once) takes about 10 hours.

Now, if you're looking for another Bastion, then you may be disappointed. Most of Transistor's combat takes place in a  turn-based mode, where you plan out your movement/attacks, then execute your plan and watch it play out. You can fight in real time (and some of the challenge trials are actually easier this way), but for the most part you'll end up taking too much damage and/or getting knocked out of your attacks to make it a very useful way to play.

Difficulty is great, in that it scales wonderfully. By default, you'll have a fairly easy time killing the Process. However, there are 10 limiters that you can choose, which will make the Process stronger, in exchange for faster leveling up. I can honestly tell you that running with all 10 limiters will make for a very harrowing experience.

Again, as I mentioned, you should totally play at least twice - first time around gives a good experience, but the second time around - when both you and the Process are leveled up, and you can start stacking functions for extra-brokeness and fun, is what really makes the game.

Final word - this is the only game that I've gone out of my way to get 100% of the achievements.

reviewText:
Very quickly going up to one of my favourite games this year, Transistor is everything I could have wanted from a Supergiant Games title.

The combat is fluid and tactical and can be played in both a real-time hack-and-slash type affair or using the tactical Turn() mechanic similar to that of V.A.T.S. in the Fallout series.

The storyline is an unsurprising ride of emotion and characterisation. The character of Transistor provides a similar commentary to Rucks in Bastion but on a much more personal level.

I can't recommend this title enough, well done Supergiant and thank you for such a great title.
